SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night we started the debate on the Representation Bill 1983. I told the Senate that this Bill seeks to repeal the existing Representation Acts and to provide, in their place, for the election of an increased number of senators. I was identifying for honourable senators the fact that the purpose of seeking an increased number of senators is to allow for an increase in the number of members of the House of Representatives. What has not been made clear is what reasons exist for an increased number of senators for the Parliament of Australia other than the desire of some people to increase the number of people in the House of Representatives. Last night I discussed whether the approach should not be to look at the question of the nexus which exists between the size of the two Houses if, indeed, the purpose which people have in mind is to obtain a larger House of Representatives. What I had not discussed last night was the fact that the public has been polled on this matter. It was asked as recently as a month ago what were its views on an increase in the size of the Federal Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: A report from the Morgan gallup poll published on 18 October this year shows quite clearly that there is overwhelming resistance from the public to the idea of a larger number of parliamentarians. The question asked of the people was: ' The Joint Parliamentary Committee on Electoral Reform recommended that the number of members for the House of Representatives be increased from 125 to 148 and that the Senate be increased from 64 to 76. Do you agree with or disagree with this recommendation?' It should be very salutary for all parliamentarians to note the response of constituents. Seventy-six per cent of people disagreed with the recommendation that the numbers in the House of Representatives and the Senate be increased. I repeat: Seventy-six per cent of our electors disagreed with that. Only 13 per cent agreed with the proposals of the Joint Select Committee that an increased number of members of parliament was desirable. We could argue here about the increased work load, we could argue about the increased complexity of Parliament, we could argue about the new functions which Parliament is taking on, we could argue about the representational duties of members of parliament, but the public does not accept the arguments. Three out of every four people polled were against it and only one out of every seven was in favour. The remainder were undecided on the question.

So there is some doubt as to why we need to press ahead at this time to seek to increase the number of members of parliament; but even if we do, no case has been advanced, as far as the Liberal Party can ascertain, to justify an increase in the number of members of the Senate. We have to ask ourselves as well what would be the consequences of having this Bill passed into law and having an increased number of senators. For a start, it would permit the House of Representatives to increase through the arrangements which exist under the nexus provided for in the Constitution. I think that is the sole reason people are seeking an increase in the number of senators. No reason which relates to the Senate as an institution or to the Senate as a chamber or to the function of the Senate or to the representation of States in the Senate has been advanced which would make an increase in numbers in this place desirable or necessary or justifiable. In the absence of such arguments there is some real doubt as to whether we should proceed to take action which in my mind will be to the detriment of the Senate and its function.

There will be some consequences of passing this Bill. The first one will be to allow more members of the House of Representatives, and that consequence is the one which is dominating the minds of those who wish to support this legislation. One of the other consequences will be in terms of resource needs, and these are not going to be inconsiderable. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is taking the Bill through the Senate, although he is temporarily absent. I hope his advisers, who are not here at the moment, I regret to say, will take on board the fact that the Hon. John Dawkins, in making a ministerial statement recently, set down that the Australian Labor Party would bring in a financial impact statement with every new Bill and every measure. I will quote Mr Dawkins' s words, and I am indebted to my colleague, Senator Lewis, for this document. Mr Dawkins said:
Another major reform involves the presentation of financial impact statements. In future all second reading speeches of Ministers will include a statement of the financial impact of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —On what date did he say that?

—I think it is September 1983. That is within the last couple of months. He said: 'I promise that there will be a financial impact statement with the second reading speech of every piece of legislation'. Now the first question at this second reading stage is this: Where is the financial impact statement for this legislation? I indicate that should we go into Committee we will ask that question again. Where is the financial impact statement and what is the financial impact of this measure? One might well look at the messages we received this morning on the health legislation and on the bank debits legislation and ask the same question. Where are the financial impact statements which the Government promised and which we suspect are not forthcoming? It is another piece of empty rhetoric. But suppose the Government was serious. What is the financial impact of this move to increase the number of senators and members? I think the public would be interested to know that the effects are not inconsiderable. I do not know what the cost of maintaining senators or members is, but it would certainly include the cost of their salaries, their parliamentary allowances, their travelling allowances while away from their home bases, the cost of their staff, the cost of their offices and equipment, the cost of their travel, and the cost of all the incidentals such as stationery.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been put to me that a member of parliament would not come any more cheaply than $150,000 a year, even excluding the costs of maintaining and supporting members' staff. Even that calculation of the cost of the extra number of members of the Parliament would come to more than $5m in a year. But in addition to that, those members would require in the Department which you administer, Mr President, extra numbers of staff, extra capital expenditure and extra maintenance. You, Mr President, would need extra Senate staff. Extra House staff would be required, and extra Joint House staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about capital expenditure?
—I am indebted to Senator Walters. Mr President, you would need extra capital expenditure to house and service these new people.
—It is going into the rooms of the people who vote for it.

—I am indebted to Senator Macklin. But I must also suggest that what we know of the plans for the new Parliament House gives us no confidence that there is provision there for the extra 36 suites that would be needed for the extra members of the Parliament. The money costs and the requirements for space will not be inconsiderable if this increase in the number of members of the Parliament takes place.

SPEECH.PARA: But the Liberal Party's main concern is that we believe that there would be political consequences from increased numbers coming into the Parliament, and that those consequences would be undesirable. Because the Senate is elected under the system that it is, it is possible to do mathematical projections to identify the percentage of votes required to establish a Senate quota and, by looking at past election results, to make some predictions about the kinds of outcomes which might result in Senate elections. Our concern as senators is for the Senate and what might happen to this chamber under a new voting system. If six senators were to be elected for each State at each half Senate election, just under 43 per cent of the formal vote would obtain quotas for three senators . It is our concern that in normal election times the two major groupings, the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal and National parties, between them will achieve three quotas immediately. That will mean two things. I see the senators of the Australian Democrats present. It would diminish the opportunity for groups such as the Democrats to gain a place in the Parliament. Going back to the last couple of elections, I think that it was only twice that the Democrats achieved full quotas, under the new figures, immediately in their own right. The rest of their quotas they built up as the count went on. We think that the first result would be that the major groupings would each get three senators on most occasions.

Secondly, we believe that it would produce a very different kind of Senate from the one that we have now. From casting my memory back over 20 years, I believe that there have been few occasions on which the government of the day has had a majority. On most occasions there has been a third grouping in the Senate, whether it has been the Australian Democrats or the Democratic Labor Party, which has had an important voting role, and governments have been able to cope and function perfectly well in that kind of situation. It has meant that the Senate has been a place of real decision and significance in the Australian political system. We are concerned that if the proposed system comes into operation we shall reach a situation in which the major groupings will between them have virtually half of the numbers in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —A hung Senate all the time.
—A hung Senate.
—Or one person controlling it.

—Or, as Senator Chipp says, one person controlling it. Some people might say that the present Senate is a hung Senate, but the present Senate is a workable political chamber in which it is possible for negotiations to be carried out and for decisions to be examined. We Liberals are concerned that the Senate as a chamber and as an institution will be diminished and weakened.
—And ultimately destroyed.
—And, as Senator Lewis says, ultimately destroyed. This is another fear-that this may be a means or a way of making the Senate less significant and less viable in the long term.
—Well, you haven't any doubt that that is the intention of the Bill, have you?

—I fear that is the intention of the Bill, as Senator Chipp says. It is another reason why we will oppose it. We oppose it, first, because there is significant public disapproval of the proposal to increase the numbers of the Parliament and, secondly, because no case has been made for a need to increase the number of senators, or for an enlarged Senate, although of course a case has been made in regard to the problems facing people in the House of Representatives. It is in fact a move with very considerable political consequences. Also, it would have certain resource consequences, which is perhaps the minor reason. I indicate that the Liberal Party will oppose this Bill at the second reading. We do not think it is in the best interests of Australian parliamentary practice or the democratic functions which this Senate is here to serve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Representation Bill 1983 to increase the numbers in the Senate and the House of Representatives was essentially brought about by a recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. That Committee had received a number of submissions arguing for an increase in the size of the Parliament. A majority of the Committee accepted a recommendation in relation to that increase. I was one of those people who agreed to that proposal. I did so because I believe that there needs to be a debate about the size of the Parliament and about associated matters. One could have gone a number of ways in the discussion in the Committee. I believed and hoped that arising out of that Committee recommendation there may have been a relatively reasonable community debate about the issue, but I suppose that was probably hoping for too much. It is an issue which, unfortunately, has been dealt with in the media in a way which was predicted by the Committee, that is, in an offhanded, anti-politician way. I suppose that is to be expected, but it is an unfortunate way of dealing with this topic.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at countries around the world similar to Australia, one notices different forms by which people tend to cope with the growing demands on their parliaments. Many parliaments have gone down the road of increasing the number of support staff. For example, in the United States of America it is not uncommon for a United States senator to have in excess of 100 staff. When one makes comparisons between the number of politicians in this country and the number of politicians in other countries, no matter on what side of the argument one falls, it is one's duty actually to present those cases in their correct light. Essentially, the correct light in which to present them is the total number of people employed in relation to the legislative process, or the total number employed in making decisions of a legislative kind. For example, comparisons between Britain and Australia have been made in the popular Press, which are false, and plainly false. They refer, for example, to the House of Commons and to Australia, as though the House of Commons were the only elected political body in the United Kingdom. People who know that particular system know that the counties have fully-employed people and that they have considerable power, power which in many cases could be equated to that of our State parliaments. For example, they run police forces and education departments . So it is important at the outset that the Australian Democrats not be painted as supporting some of the rather odd and false arguments that are floating around in opposition to this particular point.

As I said, a comparison with the United States may well incline us to increase the support staff of each senator from two to over 100. The cost of that, of course, would be astronomical. When we are talking about costs, we must bear in mind the variety of systems available and open to us. Another method open to us is also pursued by the United States. Instead of the rather interesting tradition we have built up, of parliamentarians jetting their way to Canberra each week, engaging in three days of legislative work and then returning to their constituencies to deal with the problems in their offices and to meet their constituents, the United States senators and members of the House of Representatives move to Washington. Not only do they move to Washington themselves but they also take their families with them. That is important from the point of view of the health and well-being of parliamentarians in the United States. They are able to lead a more reasonable existence-a more human existence , if I may put it that way. I believe that in many cases that ability to live with one's family and enjoy a normal home environment would be an added advantage for the legislative work that parliamentarians carry out. That is an alternative which unfortunately has not been raised in this debate.

What we have gone for instead is a very simplistic view; that is, when the pressures build up we go for more members. That is a view taken by many people in this country. It is a view that more is necessarily better. I do not think it is. When we are confronted with problems in 1983 it is at least imperative, and I would have thought obligatory, that we look at more lateral ways of dealing with those problems. I do not happen to believe that increasing the numbers of parliamentarians will necessarily mean that we will have better legislation. The realities are that, if the numbers remain the same and if the political party organisations remain the same, all we will have is different numbers when the final count is taken. If the Australian Labor Party wins government at the next House of Representatives election, the only difference we will see in terms of legislation in the House of Representatives will be larger numbers on the division lists in Hansard. The legislation itself will not necessarily be improved by having more parliamentarians. I do not think that that can be disputed. So we cannot make out an argument for needing more parliamentarians to conduct our primary role-that is, our legislative role. Increased numbers will not alter that role in any way at all in the House of Representatives.

I must admit, the work that is done within the electorate could be enhanced, as it ought to be enhanced, by having more parliamentarians. I cannot say that it necessarily will follow but it should follow that the smaller numbers of electors with which each parliamentarian in the House of Representatives has to deal will mean that members will have more time and hopefully greater opportunity to deal with and resolve the individual problems of electors.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be smaller distances, too.

—Yes, obviously there will be smaller distances to be covered in many parts of Australia, and that is important. One of the issues that the Committee was concerned with was the problem in relation to large country electorates. I believe that some consideration has to be given to that particular argument. However, when one comes to the Senate, one is confronted with a very serious and, I believe, long term problem, that the proportional representation system as it has been implemented around the world is variously accepted by people in those communities depending upon how accurately it portrays the feeling of the electorate. The Australian Democrats are extremely strong proponents of the proportional representation system. The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform put in its report on electoral reform not so long ago. I submitted a minority report urging that proportional representation ought to be applied to the House of Representatives as well because I believe it is the best system to reflect the varying views within the community.

SPEECH.PARA: A few weeks ago I had the privilege of being a member of a parliamentary delegation to Japan. I had discussions with members of the House of Councillors which has just introduced half proportional representation, that is, half of the members of the House of Councillors are elected by proportional representation. I was also able to talk to a large number of women who, for the first time in that society, had gained significant representation in the Japanese Diet. I think it is interesting that the Senate was the first house of parliament, really, to pioneer having increasing numbers of women members. It is also in this House that those parties which have minority support within the community, such as my own, are able to gain a voice in the Federal parliament.

I think this is extremely important, when one looks at the experience of Ireland. The Republic of Ireland, the Catholic section of Ireland, is used to proportional representation. It has always managed to incorporate Protestants within its parliamentary structure at the highest level. They have been part of the ruling structure. They have been incorporated in to the places where decisions are made and therefore that sectarian violence that we know occured in the north, which has a first past the post electoral system, did not occur in the south. Indeed, the President of Eire has on most occasions been a Protestant . Eamon de Valera, for instance, the person who held the presidency of that country longer than any other, was a Protestant. The system by which significant minority voices within the community are able to be heard at the highest level is extremely important for the well-being of the society and for the democratic structures.

Our concern is indeed with the proportional representation system and with maintaining it in this chamber. This chamber, despite the fact that it is elected on State boundaries one could believe that it would be by and large much further away from representing the views of the electorate than the House of Representatives has consistently been closer, in terms of numbers, to the percentage support for each political party. This is the case despite the fact that we have such disparate population sizes in this country, as exemplified by Tasmania and New South Wales. The power of that system I think has been shown by how it is able to overcome such disparities and have an elected chamber the numbers of which are closer to the percentage support for the parties than is the case in the House of Representatives. So I think that we have to think very carefully of any move which could in any way bring into disrepute the proportional representation system. I believe that this Bill has within it that possibility. In saying that, one has to make assumptions and I admit first of all that in this particular area of political life making assumptions about what will happen tommorrow is an extremely dubious occupation. That well-known phrase 'a day is a long time in politics' sums up the difficulty of trying to predict what might occur in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Malcolm Fraser found out this year.

—As indeed he did. One cannot say that certain things are going to happen. I want to make a few comments about what I feel could happen in the future. I would like to point out a few facts about the parties and independents that have from time to time gained representation in this place since the proportional representation system was introduced in 1949. As a result of elections held between 1951 and 1983, some 207 groups in the various States have gained representation in this chamber. Of those groups only one-that is one out of 207-has gained a percentage higher than 57.1 per cent and that was the Liberal-National team in Queensland in the 1975 election. I think nobody in this chamber would disagree with me that we would be very surprised if that combination occurred again this century.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, one is making a reasonable prediction about the future when one says that no party is likely to gain 57 per cent of the vote in any Senate election in any State in the foreseeable future. Looking at the various figures that are around, that is about the only prediction I feel I could make. However, that is sufficient for the argument I wish to present that no party-and here, of course, I am talking basically about the major parties, that is, the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal-National coalition parties-will be able to gain a majority in this chamber in the foreseeable future. That argument, of course, is also based on a further assumption that we will have half Senate elections. In the case of a double dissolution, the Festival of Light will probably be represented here. If that is what the Labor Party wants, it is welcome to it.

The situation is that in the foreseeable future we are looking at a situation in which neither of the major parties will have a majority in this chamber. On the other hand, I think it is pretty difficult to predict the percentage of the vote parties will receive. On many occasions the vote of the major parties, due to a combination of factors, has dropped below 43 per cent. Basically, since 1951 the percentage of the vote received by the major parties has been affected, firstly, by Democratic Labor Party percentages. It has been affected by Australian Democrat percentages since the foundation of my party. In some States it has been affected by the percentages of independents such as Senator Harradine and, in my own State, former Senator Bonner who polled a very large percentage of the vote at the last election. The situation, then, is very difficult to predict.

However, one knows that the possibilities are certainly there in half Senate elections, which under ordinary circumstances are subject to voting fluctuations , for the percentage of votes polled by the two major parties to fall within the 43 per cent to 57 per cent range. The percentage of votes polled by the major parties normally has fallen within this range for some time. It is impossible to say whether the votes will fall within this range in the future. The percentage will not exceed 57 per cent. However, of course, the percentage of the vote could, as happened in the case of the Australian Labor Party on many occasions in the 1960s, drop well below that range.

The point I want to raise is that if that circumstance prevails there could be a block in the Senate which holds half the seats with less than 50 per cent of the vote. That has to be a possibility when an even number of senators stand. Proponents or supporters of the proportional representation system demand that when that system is used the number must always be an odd number. That means that a party or group of people who gain more than 50 per cent of the vote get a majority of seats. That is an essential element of the proportional representation system. To make that system work and to retain its democratic base the number must be an odd number.

What we have here is the possibility of a party gaining 43 per cent of the vote and getting three seats and another party gaining 57 per cent of the vote, 14 per cent more, and still getting only three seats. That is the essential problem that is being built into the system by an even number. I am not able to predict- I do not think Senator Robert Ray who will speak after me is able to predict- what will happen. We can take educated guesses but that is about as far as we are all able to go. But we know that we are setting up a system which is building in the possibility of a party, wandering around the base line of 43 per cent or 44 per cent, being able to come into this chamber when it reassembles with half the number of senators. In this chamber under the Constitution that is the magic number. That group, despite the fact that it does not have the support of the majority of people within this democracy, would be able to prevent any Bill passing this chamber. At the moment for a Bill to pass this chamber it has to be supported by those senators who have the majority of votes in the community. No Bill can pass this chamber without senators voting for it who constituted over 50 per cent of the vote in the March 1983 election. That will not be the case after this Bill is passed.

That, essentially, is the undemocratic nature of introducing an even number and using a proportional representation system to achieve the election. In future, a minority of the community will be able to control the Parliament, not just this chamber. There will be a blocking mechanism in the Senate, supported by less than 50 per cent of the electorate, which can defeat any Bill. That is not the case now. It has not been the case in this chamber since 1949. On every occasion since 1949 the group to pass a Bill in this chamber has had to be the group supported by over 50 per cent of the electorate. Senator Robert Ray is entitled to look at the figures. He will see that that is the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in 1975.
—Yes, in 1975 too.
—Not after Petersen appointed Field.
—I accept that point. It is perfectly correct and the people have already deliberated on it and changed it. That was an undemocratic act.
—So I am right.

—Senator Robert Ray is correct on that point. Since the people have changed the Constitution that no longer can be the case but, with this Bill , we are again introducing that possibility in this chamber. Whereas two replacements were against the wishes of the electorate and they essentially created in this place numbers at that stage that was not representative of the people, by this very vote that possibility will be built into the system. I think that is the danger. Whether or not it will occur will depend, obviously, on a whole range of possibilities and items. For example, it will depend on whether the next election is a half Senate election, in which case seven senators will be elected. As a result of that election, with the odd number to be elected, the 50 per cent ratio will again be maintained, but only because seven are to be elected. The half Senate election after that will be the first of a number as a result of which eventually this place can get to the point at which less than 50 per cent of senators will be able to control it.

SPEECH.PARA: I appeal to the Australian Labor Party to think about that item. As was often said in the Joint Committee's deliberations, it is very difficult to make decisions in this area. If one makes a decision and thinks it is in one's interest, the horrible thing is that eventually it rebounds on one. I believe that what is proposed is essentially also depriving the Labor Party of that opportunity but I suppose, looking back, since 1949 it has not had the opportunity very often; so it might not worry terribly much about losing the opportunity. However, I do believe that it has supported and has argued for on many occasions, notably in 1975, that notion of a democratic base for this chamber. I believe that the proposed move will present a possibility of destroying that notion and destroying it in a very real way.

What will happen to the Australian Democrats in that situation is difficult to predict. If we fall between the 43 per cent and the 57 per cent we will disappear completely. Given these numbers, that obviously is on the cards. Then again, the possibilities could be otherwise, given a combination of double dissolutions and the like. The long term viability and survival of any political party in this place is not as important as is maintaining the democratic nature of both chambers and, because of the power of this chamber vis-a-vis the House of Representatives, essentially the democratic nature of this chamber. It is so finely balanced that it can be upset easily. This Bill purports, by increasing the numbers, to give greater representation to the people. In effect, while it has that as its ostensive reason, it moves to take away from the people that majority rule which is such an important ingredient in a democracy. That is why the Australian Democrats oppose this increase.

On a previous occasion I introduced in this chamber a Bill, which was subsequently passed, to break the nexus. We believe that there is a case for a reasonable increase in the size of the House of Representatives. For example, there is a case for at least an additional seat in Victoria, which is about to lose one because Queensland's population has risen. There is a case for more seats in South Australia because of the quota, the numbers in each seat in that State, and the possibility that under the current arrangement it will never be able to get another seat. Therefore the people of South Australia are disadvantaged vis-a-vis the people of the rest of Australia. If one took both of those instances into account one would be looking at consequential increases of the order of five or six. That is reasonable, I think, at this time. We believe that an attempt to break the nexus, if accepted by the people, would allow the House of Representatives, on those occasions when it was demanded by various movements of population, to make sensible and reasonable increases from time to time and that, at an appropriate time in the future, the Senate would then move from a representation of 10 to 14 senators from each State should that be thought desirable. I believe that if, in fact, the Senate committee system continues to improve and to do the work that it has done there are some reasonable arguments for looking at that at some time in the future. But unfortunately what we have here is, in fact, a proposal which manages to give us the worst of all possible worlds. We are to increase the number of parliamentarians against the wishes of the people. I have heard various estimates-Senator Ray might like to give an estimate when he speaks- of the number of people who would be likely to support this proposal if they were asked . I suppose that one might be generous and suggest that the figure is 10 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten per cent of Australians would support this.

—I think it is probably about that. In that situation, with so few people supporting this proposition, it seems to me that one needs excellent reasons for pursuing it. I readily admit that on many occasions proposals pass this chamber which might not have the overwhelming and enjoyable support of the entire community. That is one of the hard decisions that this chamber makes from time to time, and so it should. So that cannot be the overriding argument. What must be the overriding argument is that we must never do anything to change the system which will make it undemocratic. That is what this Bill will do if it passes this chamber today. It will present the possibility of the Parliament of Australia being controlled by people who have less than 50 per cent support in the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — Of course I oppose the concept of increasing the number of members of parliament. I believe that at present, although our workload has increased, there are other ways by which we can overcome that. I was pleased to read two minority reports dealing with the size of the Parliament in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. Senator Sir John Carrick, a member of that Committee, drew attention to a number of questions. I would like to read them. At page 235 he states:

SPEECH.PARA: However, a number of questions emerge and require answers:
Is there justification for a larger Senate, whether to fulfil its evolving responsibilities or simply to enable the enlargement of the House of Representatives?

Is a Senate of 72 members (plus territorians) a workable figure or would it incline to deadlocks (i.e. 3-all in each State in a half Senate election) or make it easier for minority groups to emerge and secure the balance of power?
Would the public now support the breaking of the nexus between the two Chambers ?

Is an increase of at least 35 parliamentarians (12 Senate and 23 House of Representatives) justifiable on work-load and, more imperatively, acceptable to the community at a time of serious economic recession?
Senator Sir John Carrick concludes by stating:

In my view, while the logic of a larger parliament is strong, the overriding restraints of the current economic period must prevail. I therefore believe that the question should be deferred and its various aspects (including the nexus) put under further study.

My experience is no doubt similar to that of other senators and members; that is , that our work load has increased considerably over the last decade or so. Apart from the normal, routine electoral matters, such as immigration, social security and health, the other work that senators do, in particular associated with their committee activities, has resulted in an additional work load which is evident in the offices of senators who are members of those committees. As Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment I noticed that whenever we conducted an inquiry into subjects such as woodchips and their impact on the environment or agent orange and its possible effect on the health of Vietnam veterans and their families these inquiries excited a lot of interest in the community, as does the work of other committees. This brings people into the offices of members of parliament making representations on special subjects such as those that require additional work to be done.

I recall that, when I was Chairman of that Committee, my research officer had to supplement the work carried out by the support staff of four on the Committee secretariat. I estimate that my research officer did 25 per cent of the work generated as a result of the Committee's operations. Admittedly, now that I am Deputy Chairman, the work load is not quite so pressing. Nevertheless, I inherit a lot of interest from the public on these various subjects to which I have referred.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could do with a lot more staff.

—I will get to that, certainly. I believe that that is the answer . The honourable senator may recall what happened in the 1970s. I tried to get hold of the Remuneration Tribunal report on this subject. The comment was made in that report that the work load of members of parliament had increased quite extensively and an increase in staff was quite justified provided the space was available to accommodate them. I suggest that many of us now have offices which are larger and could well accommodate extra staff. I think that is the way we ought to go.

SPEECH.PARA: The cost of providing office space for 35 or 36 new members of the House of Representatives and the Senate in the complex that is being built on Capital Hill at the moment would be quite considerable. I tried to get some estimate as to the cost of providing office space for those members but it is not possible at the moment. I know that the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House has called for designs to be carried out. Until those designs are brought forward and estimates are made that figure is not available at the present time but I imagine that it would run into millions of dollars. I believe that the salaries for 35 additional members, their staff, their travelling and other allowances to which they are entitled would amount to a considerable sum. In the current economic climate this is unacceptable not only to me and my colleagues in the Liberal Party on this side of the House but also would be resoundingly objected to by the electorate at large.

My answer to the problem at this stage is that the Government should consider increasing the staff for members of parliament. I think we should have, say, an additional junior research officer and a junior stenographer in our electorate offices as undoubtedly the work of a research officer would considerably increase the work load on the secretarial assistant. In my case-I have no doubt that Senator Elstob and other honourable senators would be in the same position- quite often I require additional assistance from the very limited staff available in the various States.

In my view two officers should be added to staff in the electorate offices of members of parliament; one junior research officer and one junior stenographer. We should also have a senior research assistant with unlimited travel capacity. I found, as a chairman of a committee, that I had to take my research officer into various parts of South Australia to help me in the work that I was required to carry out. That, of course, has to be done at the expense of members or senators. Honourable senators would know that we have a very limited capacity at the moment to bring our research officer or electorate secretary to Canberra. Having regard to the important work that we are required to do, in the committee areas as well as others, I believe that we should have a research officer with unlimited capacity to accompany us wherever we go. I am sure that all honourable senators occasionally find themselves interstate addressing a dinner meeting, a conference or a congress of some sort. On these occasions it is invaluable to have the back-up support of a research officer to relieve the member or senator of the responsibility of having to contact his office during the day. He can get reports from the officer accompanying him, thus saving a lot of time.

An example was given of the United States of America. It is difficult to compare the Australian system with that of the United States because it has a different system. I was fortunate to represent Australia at a science and technology policy conference in Ottawa about three years ago. I was also fortunate in having with me our scientific adviser from Washington, by courtesy of the Ambassador and the Department of Foreign Affairs. Eight other Commonwealth countries were represented, together with the United States of America, which was the guest country. Congressman Brown, the Chairman of the Science Committee of the Congress, attended with two of his senior advisers, who were very highly qualified and, I expect, suitably paid. I was informed that his personal staff was something like 19 and that the committee's support staff was of the order of 40. I was also informed that Senator Kennedy's personal staff runs up to something like 90. I agree that it is difficult for us to compare Australia with America because of the different systems that are employed. However, those figures give honourable senators an idea of the situation in America.

I understand money is made available to congressmen and senators in a lump sum. They can use that money to employ the staff they believe is necessary, and I understand that the political parties provide some back-up support for the Congress and the Senate. When one looks at a senator who has 90 staff and chauffeur-driven cars, it makes our work load seem quite a lot heavier. I was interested to read a report on this subject from the Institute of Public Affairs . In making one or two points, I refer to paragraph 2.6.4 on page 8, which deals with increasing Parliament's authority. It states:
In 1981 the Senate Select Committee (Jessop Committee) on Parliament's Appropriations--

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you tell us who wrote it?
—It is a report from the Institute of Public Affairs. Obviously it is intelligent comment as it refers to the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing.
—Tell us Chris Puplick wrote it.

—Was it? He is an intelligent observer. I must say that Senator Grimes's colleagues on the back bench should be grateful for the work which is being done as a result of that Select Committee's recommendations and what will be done in the future as a result of the Senate now being able to have some say in the running of Parliament, divorcing us to a large extent from the influence of the Executive Government. That is quite important. I was very grateful at the time for the tremendous support given by the now President, Senator McClelland, who was the Deputy Chairman of that Committee. However, allow me to read on. It does not really matter who the author is because I think he is certainly an intelligent observer. He goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Senate Select Committee . . on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing led to some changes to give the Parliament power to control its own internal affairs, which had previously been very much in the hands of the Executive. This imbalance between the Executive and the Legislature still needs further attention, and any improvement in the powers of the Parliament in this regard would allow Members to do a more effective job on behalf of their constituents.

I think that is quite an intelligent observation. I believe that the majority of the Senate would agree with that. I would like to refer to another minority report. I think it is important to read this report to the Senate. It was made by Mr Steele Hall who was the Deputy Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. Dealing with the size of Parliament, on page 243 of that report, he states:
There are 189 Members in the Federal Parliament and 562 Members in the six State Parliaments.

Collectively therefore 751 Members of Parliament serve the public and compete for politicial approval. They are joined by 19 Members of the Northern Territory Assembly and the Australian Capital Territory Assembly of 18.
Quite obviously the different Parliaments operate with their own Constitutions and State Administrations are confined to their own borders.
However, they are all part of a federal system and Commonwealth electors are also State electors.
The public view is that there are politicians all over the place and one has only to attend public functions to find this to be often the situation.
Taking all 788 politicians including members of the two Assemblies into the calculation, Australia has a Member to each 12000 electors.
The public would rightly be offended if the size of Federal Parliament was increased at a time when many businesses are reducing the number of their employees because of recession.
An increase in Members would inevitably swell the bureaucracy and put a stamp of approval on its growth when much of Australia is asking for smaller government.
My view does not hold that there should never be an increase. Population growth will make this desirable probably at the end of the century.
In the meantime, Members of Federal Parliament and the public would be well served by an increase in electorate office staff.
The work load of electorate offices is continually increasing as media influence and Member involvement in it grows.
Additional assistance in this way for Members to fulfill their representational role will allow them more time for their legislative and parliamentary duties.
In particular, more country electorates should receive more special assistance related to multiple office needs and travel allowances.

I agree with that. I believe that that is the sensible, economic approach that would meet with general public approval. If we, as a parliament, approve the increase in members we will be subject to massive criticism. We would thoroughly deserve that criticism. I suggest that we should vote on this matter with care and consideration giving account to the economic state of Australia and to the fact that the Government and everyone else is trying to come to grips with the economic problems associated with the massive administration that the Federal Parliament has. We are encouraging people to draw in their belts a bit and economise to try to haul ourselves out of this recessionary period. I think that the Federal Parliament ought to lead and give an example in a responsible way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have hoped that when the Representation Bill came before the Senate it would have been able to attract bipartisan support, but from today's debate it is obvious that it will not. It seems to me that there are about three different levels of response from the Liberal Party of Australia. First, there are those like Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Peter Baume who take the high road and oppose the increase on the basis that it is not an appropriate time because of the economy; that it may bring about problems in terms of the future functioning of this House and that, in fact, we should go via the Constitution to break the nexus. These are perfectly honest and straightforward arguments. I will seek later on to meet those arguments.

SPEECH.PARA: There is the second approach of the Liberal Party, taken by a couple of members of the House of Representatives and others, which I call the low road, which is really the snouts in the trough argument; that is, that we do not need any more politicians. What they are really doing, of course, is making a populist appeal to attract cheap political points. I think that demeans politicians and this Parliament and I think they will live to regret it. There is, of course, a third section of the Liberal Party, that only ever talks to members in the corridors, who hope they will win the argument today but, by cripes, they hope the Bill will go through. They again are probably a minority of the Liberal Party.

Senator Jessop summed up one of the major objections to this Bill; that is, that there are 788 politicians to 15 million Australian citizens. This objection fails to make a proper assessment by not asking: Are there enough Federal politicians to carry out the task properly? I think there are not enough, but I certainly agree that there are too many State politicians. It is interesting to look at the figures. The last time this House was increased was in 1949. Let us look at what happened in the States from 1949 to 1983. In my home State of Victoria in 1949 in the Legislative Assembly there were 66 seats. Today, following a redistribution, there will be 88 seats. There has been a 25 per cent increase in the size of the lower House in Victoria. In New South Wales there were 82 seats in 1949, and today there are 99. That represents a 17 per cent increase in that State. In Queensland in 1949 there were 62 seats, and today there are 81. That is a 25 per cent increase in the size of the lower House there. South Australia has gone from 39 to 47 in the same period, a 17 per cent increase. Western Australia has gone from 50 to 57, a 14 per cent increase. Finally, even Tasmania has gone from 30 to 35 in that same period, a 15 per cent increase.

Each State lower House has been increased since 1949. I cannot remember whether , by my research or anything else, any Liberals or anyone else objected to increasing the size of those parliaments. In fact in most cases the Liberals were the sponsors of the increases. I think we had better realistically look at the actual size of increase we are suggesting-about a 16 per cent increase in the House of Representatives. We are not going for some absolutely gigantic increase in the size of the Parliament. It will mean that there will be an average throughout Australia of 65,000 electors per electorate. It is valid to compare the position with that in the United Kingdom where there are 47,186 electors per electorate, or Canada where there are 56,026 electors per electorate in the lower House. Those countries have a similar Westminster system to our own.

I also draw the attention of the Senate to the increases that have occurred since 1949. To illustrate that point, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table on page 137 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The table shows that New South electorates are now 82 per cent bigger than they were in 1949. In Queensland there is a 111 per cent higher enrolment per electorate than in 1949. Even if we bring about an increase in the size of the House of Representatives, in not one State will any seat be less than 50 per cent bigger than they were in 1949. We are not going back to the relativities of 1949. So honourable senators can see that there has been a massive increase in enrolment per seat, which makes those seats much more difficult to service.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall put forward some positive reasons why the Senate should support this legislation. First of all I refer to the Queensland National Party's submission to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. That submission, in a very stark way, highlighted the problems created by the tyranny of distance in certain seats; that is, that certain seats were of enormous size and were very hard to service and that any equalisation in the enrolment of seats would worsen the position in those seats. The National Party suggested, of course, that the easy way of handling this problem is to have a 20 per cent bias in favour of those seats. Knowing the philosophy of the Australian Labor Party, honourable senators will realise that we could never support that sort of distortion in the electoral process. The only way we will ever deal with the problem of the tyranny of distance is by increasing the number of seats, thereby reducing the size of rural seats.

Let us look at some remote seats. I do not want to bore everyone with statistics, but they are relevant. The largest seat is Kalgoorlie which has an area of 2,324,081 square kilometres. That electorate at the moment is only about 863 voters below quota, so it probably will get only an additional 1,000 voters after the next redistribution. That means that it will probably also pick up 20, 000 or 30,000 extra square kilometres, which I guess in the context of two million square kilometres is not that much. The seat of Grey comprises 890,584 square kilometres and its enrolment is already 5,386 below quota. Come the redistribution, it will need 8,000 new electors. Where will it get from? The size of Grey, which already constitutes 90 per cent of South Australia, will be increased, presumably to 92 or 94 per cent of South Australia.

Let us look at the National Party seats in Queensland. The electorate of Kennedy is over 600,000 square kilometres in size. At the moment it is 13,350 below quota, which means that it will have to pick up 18,000 extra electors after the next redistribution. One can imagine the size to which that seat will grow. The electorate of Maranoa covers over 500,000 square kilometres and is 9, 000 below quota, so it will presumably have to pick up 13,000 extra electors after the next redistribution. The seats of Leichhardt and Riverina will be similarly affected.

There is one common thread between those six electorates: The National Party holds three and the Labor Party holds three. Obviously we are concerned about their size. The Liberal Party does not hold any big electorates, so why should they care less? If we go ahead with a redistribution without increasing the size of the House of Representatives, we will make some of these seats massive in size and very difficult to service-far more difficult than they are at the moment.

The second major argument in favour of increasing the size of this Parliament relates to the new responsibilities that the Parliament has undertaken since 1949. I list some of those areas with which we now deal and with which we did not deal in 1949: Aboriginal affairs, a far more extensive social welfare responsibility, a far greater role in education, environment and conservation, family law, legal aid, ethnic affairs, consumer affairs, child care, minerals and energy policy, tourism, small business, sport and recreation, cultural affairs, science and technology, communications and overseas aid. The list goes on and on. All those new areas of responsibility have been given to the Federal Parliament since 1949, yet there has not been an increase in the Parliament's capacity to deal with them other than perhaps in the quality of its membership.

The third major reason why I think we should support this legislation relates to a good reason for increasing the size of the Senate. One of the arguments from the other side of the chamber is: 'We can see that there is a reason to increase the size of the House of Representatives but there is no real reason to increase the size of the Senate'. I suggest that honourable senators opposite look at the way in which the Senate committee system is running at the moment. It is at breaking point, in my view. In this chamber just the other day we had a debate on whether to set up a select committee on animal welfare. The relevant question was not whether that was a good issue to inquire into, but from where we would get members of the Senate to serve on it. Therefore, Senator Chipp suggested that we have a committee of four. Senator Chaney asked why that was necessary. It is because that is what would be workable. Not enough of us have the time to serve on so many committees. Committees are seeking to meet while the Senate is sitting because that is the only time available. We have people serving on two or three committees. In the recess they have to run from one committee to another to serve this Parliament.

Let us take the situation in the Labor Party which has 30 senators, six of whom are Ministers and do not serve on committees, and one of whom is the President, who does not serve on committees. That leaves a pool of 23 people to serve on all the standing committees-the Privileges Committee, Standing Orders Committee, Joint House Committee and all the other committees. We are reaching the point where the senators themselves no longer participate in the committee process. It is the research staff and the staff who write reports who have the greatest involvement. Honourable senators do not give proper consideration to those reports. When we are trying to cover so many areas, we might as well just remove the senators from committees and tell the staff that we want a report on one subject or another. There is a case for enlarging the numbers in this chamber.

It is often said that enlargement will be costly. I just point out that most Senate committees represent the cheapest possible form of inquiry we can get. Let us consider, say, the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs inquiring into a crimes body Bill. All up, the cost of that may be $30, 000 or $40,000. If we had appointed a royal commissioner to investigate that subject, we would have been up for an expenditure of $3m or $4m. Honourable senators opposite should not bring up the cost argument and say that electing more politicians will necessarily cost more. It is a lot cheaper to have parliamentarians conduct inquiries than to have royal commission judges conduct them.

TALK.START.PARA: —And do a better job.

—And do a better job; Senator Teague is right. We do not know what the result of the cost-benefit analysis of having more politicians would be , but it would not include an automatic cost of $5m or $10m per year. This place could run more efficiently. Matters like medifraud could have been picked up earlier and this could save money rather than cost money.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to raise a more philosophical matter and that is the relationship between the Ministry and the back bench of the governing party. My remarks are relevant to both the Liberal Party and the Labor Party. At the moment we have 27 Ministers out of a parliamentary party of 105 members. What that tends to lead to, although it has not become too evident in the Labor Party as yet, is domination by the Executive of the rest of the party which is in power. I am sure that this happened with the Liberal Party, especially as there was Cabinet solidarity. In our case we have 27 people in the Ministry and they tend to dominate. The figure of 105 members is unusual for the Labor Party. We tend to govern with 90 or 93 members in normal times. In that case one-third of the governing party will be in the Ministry. I think that is an appalling ratio and it is a ratio which we should try to change if we really believe in the future of the institution of Parliament and in a proper system of government.

I now turn to some of the Liberal Party objections. One which has not been voiced here today, but which I have heard before, is that we have accommodation problems around this place and that an extra 35 people would be hard to fit in. Having just been removed from my room a few months ago so that the wall could be cut down to make a gigantic suite for someone or other-good luck to whoever it is-I can say that there is, and there was, room in this place for another 35 people and it can be found. I dare say that some people in the Parliament-maybe not everyone in this chamber-are willing to make a sacrifice and have one of their fellow politicians share a room with them. I do not think that is a particularly relevant factor; nor is it relevant to say that the new Parliament House cannot take an extra 35 people. If that is the case, and I do not dispute it one way or the other, I suggest we sack a couple of architects, because surely they should have anticipated that at some stage, maybe not next year or the year after, this Parliament would have to be increased in size.

Let me turn to the second argument which is the nexus argument. I really find it very amusing. It is put up in all sincerity by some people who say: 'Look, the strongest case for expanding parliament is in the House of Representatives', I concede that, 'therefore let us break the nexus'. As someone who spent 10 hours in a polling booth in 1967 and listened to all that anti-politician, philistine argument which was produced then and will be produced again in 1983 or whenever that referendum proposal is put, I feel that we probably will not get it through. The Liberal Party is the victim of a double pincer movement. By putting up that proposal it is a victim of those who say there should be no more politicians, and that sort of argument is very easy to run. There will be plenty on Senator Peter Baume's side who say that States' rights are being hurt by breaking the nexus between the House of Representatives and the Senate.

Honourable senators should remember that in the 1967 referendum it was the no- politician argument which won the day in Victoria and Queensland, but in South Australia and Western Australia it was the States' rights issue which killed the referendum. If I thought that every Liberal Party member opposite would support the breaking of the nexus, I would be very happy to support it. But there are always narks on that side. There are always people who, for whatever reason, will say: 'There will be no change. We cannot gave that'. There is very little chance, of course, that we could realistically put up the nexus proposal in the 1984 February referendums. I think everyone concedes that five referendums is about the maximum to put to the people at one time. I do not rule out, and I certainly do not think that the Labor Party rules out, the possibility that in the next round of referendums, whenever they may be, we will put the nexus proposal to the people to decide once again. I look forward to some of those people, who today have given it such strong support, giving it adequate support.

A third argument put up by the Liberal Party-I have not heard it here but I heard it in the House of Representatives and saw it in the document of the Institute of Public Affairs-is that this proposal advantages the Labor Party. Opponents of the proposal have done some quick calculations. They say that if there are to be an extra 23 seats in the House of Representatives, 14 will go to Labor and nine will go to the coalition. I have yet to meet anyone on the other side who can do those calculations accurately. I pride myself on being able to do such things. No one, but no one, could make those sorts of predictions realistically. But I accept that that argument is probably right. That reflects the majority in the House of Representatives at the moment. If we repeat our 1983 voting figures in an expanded parliament I expect that we would get 14 seats and the coalition would get nine. I expect that if the Liberal party repeated or reversed the result in terms of primary votes and preferences, it would get 14 seats and we would get nine seats. So it is not really an argument. I do not think there is any real political advantage.

TALK.START.PARA: —The argument rests here in the Senate, not in the House of Representatives.

—I will come to that in a moment. I will also deal with Senator Sir John Carrick's major objection because it was a rather considered minority report by him. I do not want to mislead the Senate as to what he said. But basically, in summary, he said that, at some stage, the size of the Parliament should be increased. The major blocking factor in his mind was that it should not be done in times of economic recession. We could now go on and argue whether the economic recession is over. But I very strongly argue that, by the time the new politicians may arrive in this place, we all hope I think-some of us confidently predict-that the worst of the economic recession will be over and that we will be on the way to recovery. So, I do not think that argument necessarily stands up.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been a whole series of arguments put by the Institute of Public Affairs, New South Wales branch, against this proposal. It is entitled to its views. It is not an objective body; it is a front organisation for the Liberal Party, a bit like the Fabian Society is for the Labor Party. We all know that it was set up by the Liberal Party to provide a different point of view. I think it serves a very useful role for intellectual stimulation for the Liberal Party. But I do not think that we should seriously consider its objections here.

Let us get to the guts of the argument. The argument has been put forward that this proposal, by increasing this chamber to 76 senators, will bring about a hung Senate. Former Senator Hall who is now the Liberal Party spokesman on this matter in the House of Representatives went on at great length about this. Senator Missen, in his comments about the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, dealt with it in detail. Senator Peter Baume and Senator Macklin from the Australian Democrats have given it great weight. In my view, this chamber has been hung for a long while. I think that, during the time of the McMahon Government, the Liberal Party did not have a majority. There was not a majority in this chamber right through the days of the Whitlam Government. Between 1980 and 1983, the Fraser Government did not have a majority in this chamber. And the Labor Party Government now, obviously, does not have a majority . Minority government representation in this chamber is the norm; government control is the exception. But to make the bald statement that no party can win a majority when there are 12 senators from each State is absolute nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I return to the basic philosophical argument. It contends that if each party gets 43 per cent of the vote the split will be three senators each. Some people argue that that is the norm. But what happens when there are five senators to be elected? The norm at the moment is that the governing party takes two, the opposition party takes two and the Democrats take one. A situation can exist in this place where the Opposition gets 34 per cent of the vote and the Government gets 48 per cent of the vote and both get two senators each. I ask honourable senators to tell me what is fair about that? That is the situation as it currently exists. The Democrats get the other position. The most likely outcome that everyone would concede in the situation of six senators coming out in a half-Senate election is that the Government, whichever it is, Liberal or Labor, will get three, the Opposition will get two and the Democrats will get one. I will go on to expand on that by looking at past results. Let us look at 1975 when there was a double dissolution . If there had been 76 senators to be elected, the Liberal Party would have won 43 positions out of 76. Quite clearly it would have had a majority in this chamber.
—That was an exceptional election.

—It was an exceptional election, but I will come to that aspect in a moment. Let us also look at it with six senators coming up for election. Let us apply that test to that same vote. The Liberal Party would have won 23 postions out of 40 of which 21 senators would have been long term. In 1977 with six senators to be elected the Liberal Party would have won 21 out of 40 seats; two of which were Territory seats. So what that comes back to is that at half Senate elections in 1975 and 1977 the Opposition would have had 40 out of 76 seats. So it is clear to me that a party can win a majority of seats in this chamber. It is not ever going to be the norm, but it can be done. I could also say that in 1980 the Liberal Party would have won 20 out of the 40 seats available at that election-two in the Territories and 18 others. That would at least have halved the Senate and, combined with the 1977 vote, would have given it a majority in this chamber, so it is possible.

SPEECH.PARA: At different times Senator Macklin has indicated that he thought the Democrats might be wiped out. I am not here to say whether that is a good or a bad thing. It is for the electorate to make that judgment, but I can assure him and others that this Bill is not designed to wipe out the Democrats. If that is a beneficial by-product, I would suggest we may not object to it, but I do not think it will be, and it was never planned to be. In 1977 the Democrats would have had four senators elected under this system of six. They got only two that year. Let us look at 1980. They had three senators elected and they would have had three elected under this system; so, they would have maintained their representation. In a double dissolution in 1983 they would have picked up six seats-they currently have five. In a half-Senate situation with six being elected they would have picked up four. If that were repeated in the following election they would have eight representatives in this chamber. A lot of assertions have been made about this being a hung Senate and everything else. Unfortunately, apart from myself, no one else appears to have done the figures. They are all guessing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Next speech.

—Next speech; but I hope that Senator Teague does not assert that 43 per cent is a magical figure that a party gets every time. Let me quote the figures back to him. In the 1975 election in only one State out of six did Labor poll 43 per cent. Where, in the election in 1977-this is the 43 per cent syndrome that Senator Peter Baume, Senator Macklin and everyone else goes on about in great detail-did the Labor Party get 43 per cent of the vote? Regretfully nowhere. That is the tragedy. Let us look at 1980. In New South Wales we get it, in Victoria we get it, in Queensland we do not, in South Australia we do not, in Western Australia we do not and in Tasmania we do not. It is an absolute fallacy to say that it is going to be a 3:3 split every time. Honourable senators can look at the Liberal Party performance in 1983 to see if that is a 3:3 split. In New South Wales it got 38 per cent and in Victoria it got 38 per cent, but in relation to Queensland let us forget about trying to add up what the real Liberal Party, National Party of Australia, Bonner vote and everything else means in Queensland because it does not make the analysis particularly interesting. In South Australia the Liberal Party got 40 per cent and in Tasmania it got 42.6 per cent. In the crown of the Liberal Party these days, Tasmania, it does not even make the 43 per cent. So this hung Senate argument that both major parties are in fact going to win an equal number of seats is absolutely farcical and I think should be dropped off the agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: Another suggestion has come from Senator Missen that we should split the senators and States up; that in one year three States elect seven senators and the other three elect five, and it is reversed the next time. In that way we are supposed to get a result. I do not know much about the Constitution but it does not appear to me to be particularly consistent when section 13 requires that:
. . . the Senate shall divide the senators chosen for each State into two classes, as nearly equal in number as practicable . . .

Five and seven does not seem nearly practicable. If we look at proposed new section 13 (3) of the legislation on the referendum for simultaneous elections it is clear that if that referendum is successful, anything carried in this Bill would be inconsistent.

In summing up I come to two final points: Why do it now? Why not leave it for a few years time? Why not do as we did with the new Parliament House legislation, debate it in 1940, 1950, 1960 and 1970? Why make a final decision now? I think the Opposition should make a decision now because of forthcoming legislation which I anticipate being passed. I do not want to anticipate it other than to say that it brings about a form of redistribution process that may make the next distribution the last of the gigantic ones, the last time that all States are done at the one time. Because of the provisions that are going to be put into the Act each State will probably be done at a different time. There will be no chance to increase the size of parliament in a few years' time. New members in this place will serve only about two years in this House before we move to the new Parliament House. That being so, I do not think that we need to delay.

I refer to one other matter. If this Bill passes this place today, we shall have a great reaction outside. Senator Baume has already indicated that he thought that 10 per cent or 12 per cent of the people support this matter, as reflected in opinion polls. If we had asked them the question 'Are you in favour of cutting politicians pay by half?', I doubt whether we would have got half way to 10 per cent. It depends on the questions asked and the background. Just consider this: The blasts that we shall get out of the media, not all of them, but a lot, will be 'snouts in the trough', 'the pollies are at it again', 'they are looking after themselves'. It is interesting to consider that we have had no increase in the size of this place since 1949, yet the size of the Press Gallery has increased fourfold. There are four times as many accredited members of the Press in this Parliament than there were in 1949.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that done for democracy?

—I think it means this, Senator Watson: Either our productivity, our quality and our abilities to deal with all the complex issues have increased fourfold or the productivity of the Press has dropped by 75 per cent. I do not know. If members of the Press, being representatives of private enterprise which is a taut, brilliant and efficient system, according to Senator Baume, have had their numbers increased by 400 per cent, this Parliament should have had its numbers bloated out by 400 per cent. This Parliament, as a government-funded socialist institution, has not increased its numbers. The reverse should have been true. Our numbers should have increased by 400 per cent , and the Press numbers should have remained the same.

SPEECH.PARA: In summing up, the case for this Bill rests on several bases. First, there has not been an increase since 1949 and electorates are getting large. Secondly, country electorates, especially in Western Australia, South Australia and Queensland, are getting to a size that is becoming ridiculous, and after the next redistribution they will increase in size yet again and become more unmanageable. Thirdly, this chamber and the Senate committee system are straining for lack of members to participate. Fourthly, the areas of responsibility of this Parliament have increased enormously since 1949. I say again that the most substantive argument brought up by the Opposition today, that this chamber will be hung because of the 43 per cent syndrome, has to be considered when looking at the figures that I have incorporated. Honourable senators may not agree with my calculations, but at least the raw percentage figures are right. The occasions on which parties poll below 43 per cent seem to me to be more common than when they poll above that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The important figure is 57 per cent.

—I suggest that Senator Macklin go back and look at the figures. I have two minutes left. I shall just go back for Senator Macklin's benefit. In 1975 the Labor Party polled over 43 per cent in one of the six States. In 1977 the Labor Party polled over 43 per cent in one State again. In 1980 the Labor Party polled over that figure in one State; et cetera. What Senator Macklin and company are arguing is a theoretical model that has no basis in past results. We cannot anticipate what future results will be. We are reaching a rather pathetic stage. If he says that the self-interest of the Australian Democrats is hurt, as a party, the past figures again disprove that. No one can anticipate the future. I commend the Bill to the House.
