TALK.START.PARA: — In this debate on the Representation Bill 1983, Senator Peter Baume has already outlined why Liberal Party senators are opposed to the Bill. Senator Sir John Carrick, in the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, also set out reasons for opposition to the Bill. I am opposed to the Bill. The bases for this opposition can briefly be summarised in this way, and these arguments have been put at much more length by my colleagues: First, the people of Australia are overwhelmingly opposed to this measure. The gallup poll of mid-October, only a month ago, found that 76 per cent of Australians oppose the specific proposal for this increase in the number of parliamentarians. Only 13 per cent were in favour; the balance, some 11 per cent, were undecided. As Liberal senators-in this we are joined by the Australian Democrats-we seek to represent this overwhelming number of Australians, and we oppose the Labor Government's Bill. Secondly, given the present difficulties in the Australian economy, now is not the time to see Parliament spending a lot more money on more and more politicians. It is wrong for Parliament to put on more politicians when so many small and large businesses all over Australia are putting off employees. This Bill means more costs, more expenditure, that Australia cannot now afford.

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, it is our view-I put this argument despite Senator Robert Ray's comments on this-that consideration should not be given to any increase until the new Parliament House is completed and opened in 1988 so that there may be the capacity, the space, the practical facilities, to accommodate any increase. Even then, that increase can be justified only for the House of Representatives and not for the Senate. The way forward, even after 1988, would be to break the nexus, so that the Senate would maintain its present number but the House of Representatives would be allowed a small increase.

The fourth argument, which I will come back to in some detail in the second half of my speech, for why this Bill should be opposed is that the arrangements for half-Senate elections that flow from it will build in a permanent deadlock, a disability in the Senate for any party to gain a majority. The prospect of a permanent stalemate in the Senate numbers will, I believe, undermine the Senate by threatening to make it unworkable. I disagree with Senator Robert Ray's conclusion on that matter. However, I agree with much of the numerical analysis that he gave, in particular with regard to the exceptional election of 1975 and its flow-on even after 1977. I will come back to that in some detail with figures later.

These four arguments have been taken up by Liberal senators. I am glad that the Democrats have taken up these arguments also. I now refer to a fifth argument, relating only to the Democrats as a minority party. This argument against the Bill amounts to a special factor which affects only the Democrats. It therefore amounts to a vested interest for them to protect. What is the Democrats' vested interest in opposing this Bill? It is not, as many allege, that it will be harder for the Democrats to be successful if we move from a five-vacancy half- Senate election, as is the case now, to a seven-member vacancy or, especially, a six-member vacancy for which this Bill provides. The allegation that that is a disadvantage to the Democrats was put by Senator Macklin. I do not agree with that allegation. It can be called the 42 per cent argument or the even-odd number argument, as Senator Macklin put it. I do not believe that it can be substantiated. I am not convinced by that argument, but I am putting forward the proposition that the vested interest of the Democrats in this Bill is something different.

In arguing against the 42 per cent argument let me go in this way. It is my assessment that there is no disadvantage to the Democrats or to any minority party in moving from a five-vacancy half-Senate election to a six- or seven- vacancy half-Senate election. In fact, to the contrary, with larger numbers in the Senate it will be in a directly corresponding way easier for a minority party candidate to be elected in a six-vacancy election than in the present five -vacancy election and easier still in a seven-vacancy election, which is provided for in the transition arrangements for the next election. Let us consider some examples. In South Australia and Victoria for both of the last two Senate elections a Democrat would have been elected whether the vacancy had been for five, six or seven senators. An analysis of the figures in each of these elections, 1980 and 1983, shows that if a minority party candidate is elected in a five-vacancy situation that candidate would have been elected in a six-vacancy situation and in a seven-vacancy situation. A 10-vacancy situation is different and does have some paradoxes which I will refer to later on.

Let us look at the figures from just one of the instances I have described; that is, South Australia in the March 1983 elections. This was a double dissolution election and there were 10 vacancies to fill. The actual outcome reflects that. The outcome, as we know, happens to have been Australian Labor Party five, Liberal Party four and Australian Democrats one. The total formal vote was 763,349. When that figure is divided, not on the basis of primary votes but at the point of establishing the quota for the last vacancy to be filled, the result is as follows: ALP 343,898; Liberal 314,493; and Democrats 104,958. Had the March 1983 election been for a five-vacancy Senate election-that is, the normal half-Senate election as Senate numbers are now-then a division of quotas corresponding to these votes would have been ALP 2.472, Liberal 2.703, and Democrats 0.825. The outcome would have been Labor two seats, Liberal two and Democrat one. Had it been a six-vacancy election, the quotas would have been ALP 3.154, Liberal 2.884, and Democrats 0.962. The outcome would have been ALP three , Liberal two and Democrats one.

This example illustrates the general case that I am maintaining, that if a minority party candidate is successful in a five-vacancy election then that candidate will be successful at a six-vacancy election and at a seven-vacancy election. Indeed, the larger the number of vacancies the easier it is for a minority candidate to be successful. I have looked at all the Democrats elections since 1977 and that conclusion can be maintained in respect of every one.

To drive home this conclusion I refer to one more example-the case where in a five-vacancy election a minority party candidate was not elected but would have been elected had the election been to fill six vacancies or to fill seven vacancies. This case is illustrated-there are a number of examples-by the half Senate election in South Australia in 1977. As we know, the outcome for the actual five-vacancy election then was Liberal three and ALP two. However, had this been a six-vacancy election the 702,218 formal votes then cast would have been divided at the point of determining the last quota for the sixth vacancy in the following way: Liberal 350,392, ALP 267,128 and Democrats 84,698. The division of quotas corresponding to these votes would have been Liberal 3.49, Labor 2.66, and Democrats 0.84. The result of that set of quotas would be Liberal three, ALP two and Democrats one. The conclusion, then-this example illustrates it-is that a minority party may just miss in a five-vacancy half- Senate election but in fact be successful in the move to a six-vacancy half Senate election. So the Democrats' vested interest, or any minority party's vested interest, does not arise from any alleged disadvantage accruing from a six-vacancy arrangement; rather, the reverse is true.

So why is it that the Democrats oppose this measure? Is it high-minded altruism ? Is it a shining example of a minority party denying its self-interest in order to be popular with the great majority of Australians who will oppose the measure ? Mr Deputy President, there is no shining example here. Rather, as I understand it, the Democrats are putting more weight into protecting another vested interest; that is, they are trying to prevent a serious disadvantage which they as Democrats will uniquely suffer if this measure proceeds. I refer to the transition arrangements in this Bill whereby at the next half-Senate election, only, there will be a seven-vacancy election and the seventh elected will be filling only a half term-that is, only a short term; not six years but only three. This transition arrangement, on the experience of all recent elections, will seriously and uniquely disadvantage Democrats. To demonstrate this point I will now describe the analysis of voting patterns in all the States. This is the vested interest, I put to the Senate, that the Democrats are protecting by opposing this measure. Senator Macklin did not refer to these transition arrangements in one sentence in his speech. The situation plainly is this: If this increase in the Senate goes ahead, then in the transition seven-vacancy half-Senate election, that is the next Senate election, the Democrats can only reasonably expect, if elected at all, to be elected in the seventh position and thus be elected for only short terms. This is especially the prospect for Senator Macklin, for Senator Jack Evans and for Senator Mason. It is also the prospect--

—Mr Deputy President, I ask Senator Macklin not to interject. I think I have him on a sensitive point. He has not disclosed a vested interest for the Democrats. I ask him not to interject.
—Senator Macklin, you should refrain from interjecting.

—The situation plainly is that if this increase in the Senate goes ahead then in the transition seven-vacancy half-Senate election, that is the next Senate election, the Democrats can only reasonable expect, if elected at all, to be elected in the seventh position and thus be elected only for a short term. This is especially the prospect in Queensland, Western Australia and New South Wales. It is also the prospect for the Democrat candidates who may contest the next election in South Australia and in Victoria. As Senator Chipp's and Senator Haines's present terms extend to the subsequent election, they themselves would not be the candidates at the next elections in those two States . In brief, the prospect is that any and all Democrats senators who may be here in the next Parliament will have their Senate terms concluding at the end of that Parliament, and that may be as early as 1987 but, depending on next February's referenda, could be in 1988 or 1989. Whilst it may be possible for a minority candidate to be successful on a six-vacancy basis in the subsequent 1987 or so election, any one or two Democrats who may then be elected will be the only Democrats in the subsequent Senate, that is, in the post-1987 or 1988 Senate. This is so because any and all Democrats in the Senate in the next Parliament will have their terms completed at the end of that Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me outline the alternative situation, that is, if this Bill fails and there is no increase in the number of senators. In this event, the next half- Senate election would lead to every elected senator gaining a long term, a term of six years, possibly extended to eight years if the referendum for the four-year term for the House of Representatives is passed in February. In this event, the Democrats may be completely unsuccessful and not gain a Senate seat in any State , but if they do have sufficient public support to gain a seat or two, it is most likely, on all past experience, that this would be in Victoria and in South Australia, and any such successful candidates would have terms extending one Parliament beyond the present terms of Senator Chipp and Senator Haines. But this continuity advantage in Victoria and South Australia will be directly lost if this Representation Bill is passed.

In summary, I believe that the Democrats' opposition to this Bill arises not only for the reasons Senator Macklin gave but also because of a vested interest that the Democrats are protecting in the transitional arrangements. This argument is not the 42 per cent argument which Senator Robert Ray rightly argued against and which I am arguing against but which Senator Macklin, nevertheless, put forward. Rather, it is a consequence of the transition arrangements in the next election. This can be summarised in this way: They want to avoid the circumstances where, firstly, continuity in Victoria and South Australia would be lost making it impossible for these two States to provide a possible four Democrats rather than a possible two Democrats after the subsequent election; and secondly, Senators Macklin, Jack Evans and Mason are looking down the barrel of its being impossible for them to achieve any more than a half term, even if that, after the next election.

Before I leave the table, I should explain that it shows two alternative results in four of the States-New South Wales, Western Australia, Queensland and Tasmania. This arises because the allocation of the preferences of the final one or two candidates in the seven-vacancy circumstance is not clearly shown in the data from the Australian Electoral Office. Accordingly, I have included figures in the table that are certain. From this point on the resolution of the final quota can only be estimated. However, in each of these four States I am confident there are only two possible outcomes. These are given in the table. In New South Wales the seventh position contest would have been between the Democrat and the fourth ALP candidate, with the outcome dependent on the preferences of the Call to Australia Party. In Tasmania, the contest for the seventh position-at that stage three Liberals, two ALP candidates and Senator Harradine having been successful; that is the first six based on the 1983 actual figures-would have been between the Democrat and the third ALP candidate. The most likely outcome would have been the Democrat gaining the seventh position at the expense of the ALP. The Queensland and Tasmanian cases then, both show the paradox of a minority candidate being unsuccessful in the actual 10-vacancy March 1983 election, nevertheless, being elected had that election been to fill seven vacancies. In Victoria, just to complete the picture, the table indicates only one outcome, that is, the Democrat gaining the seventh position. TALK.START.PARA: —What are you talking about?

—I am talking about the flow from the actual 1983 result if there had been a seven-vacancy analysis. For my part, I think it is reasonable to say that the minority parties are likely to do less well but that is a matter for the electorate to determine at the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: In my final remarks I wish to concentrate on the effect that this Bill will have on the majority parties, that is, the Liberal-National coalition and the ALP. The effect of this Representation Bill 1983 on the majority parties will be enormous in that, unlike the present situation it will, in practice, deny both major parties the opportunity of ever gaining a majority in the Senate. This Bill is opposed by the Liberal Party chiefly for this reason. It is for me the principal reason for opposing this Bill. With the proposed enlarged Senate it is virtually certain that at the end of the next Parliament the continuing senators , that is, next Parliament's long term senators, will comprise 18 Liberal- National coalition senators and 18 ALP senators. This 18: 18 residue from the next Parliament is virtually certain for the detailed reason I have already outlined, that is, that the first six senators to be elected at the next election, that is the seven-vacancy election, are virtually certain to be, in all six States, three Liberal-National Party senators and three ALP senators. The table I have incorporated shows clearly in the case of 1983--

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to Brian?

—I agree that Senator Harradine would have made it but I am arguing-if Senator Macklin had listened to me he would know-that I do not believe that the Harradine party will do as well in the next election. The table I have incorporated shows clearly in the case of 1983-the same is true for 1980, 1977 and all recent elections-that the first six senators elected for each State next time will be divided three each between the major parties. Just as importantly and with even more certainty it will be the case that neither major party will gain a majority in the Senate; that is, neither the ALP nor the Liberal- National Party coalition can ever expect to gain 39 seats in the Senate . This is so because if one minority candidate is elected in any one election the Senate numbers will be 38, 37 and one. If two are elected the numbers will be 37, 37 and two or 38, 36 and two, and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not possible in practice for a major party to gain the magic majority number of 39 seats because that would mean one of the major parties gaining four of the six available Senate vacancies. To move from winning three seats to winning four seats requires an extraordinary and almost unprecedented State-wide preferential vote of 57.14 per cent-in this I agree with Senator Macklin-rather than 42.86 per cent. Clearly, the 57 per cent goal will, on the whole history of Senate voting, be virtually unattainable. In addition to the example I have already given of Queensland in 1975, I have found only one other instance and that is South Australia in the same election. In all the elections of the last 40 years only those two examples, I believe, would have allowed any party to gain the 57.14 per cent of the State-wide preferential vote which would allow four of the six vacancies to be won by one party and hence allow the possibility of a majority being gained in the Senate.

As my time has almost elapsed, I summarise by saying that the Democrats oppose this legislation for some of the reasons that the Liberal Party opposes it. We share substantial reasons but, in addition, the Democrats, in opposing the transition arrangements, have a vested interest which has not been discussed by them. It is fully displayed and can be comprehended by anybody who reads the analysis I have set out in the table I have had incorporated in Hansard. I urge honourable senators to oppose this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: — It must be Friday because we have been treated to one of those peculiar speeches in which Senator Teague, in opposing the Representation Bill, sounded as if he were supporting it. In a long dissertation he spent a lot of time telling the Australian Democrats what was in their best interest, only to be heavily heckled by Senator Macklin, representing the Democrats, denying that what he said was in the Democrats' best interest. On behalf of the Government I wish the Opposition parties would get their act together and present a united front. It would make debate easier in terms of identifying what they are opposing.
—You will be voting with the National Party on this issue, will you not?

—From time to time the National Party shows great good sense and it is to be commended for that. The Bill increases the number of parliamentarians because of the increase in the sizes of electorates and the population of Australia. In supporting this Government measure, I commend to the Senate the speech delivered a short while ago by Senator Robert Ray, who I believe canvassed all the main issues completely and comprehensively. I am disturbed to see, however, that earlier today Senator Baume and just now Senator Teague, in starting their addresses, referred to popular opinion polls as an argument why this Bill should not go forward. Anyone who relies on popular sentiment in the superficial way in which it is bandied about in this chamber is relying on capricious, contradictory and muddled reasoning. Popular sentiment has it that taxes should be decreased but pensions and other government outlays should be increased. Popular sentiment has it that all wage increases are wrong but my personal wage increase is right. Popular sentiment has it that strong leaders are desired but we also like to cut down tall poppies. So popular sentiment is indeed a capricious and conradictory being. Anyone who wishes to rely upon it, as Senator Baume and Senator Teague have done, is really just taking a soft option for a superficial input to a serious debate justifying perhaps the popular sentiment that all politicians are cads and what we really want in this country is not politicians but statesmen.

SPEECH.PARA: The key aspect of the polls that have been raised here as some evidentiary base for opposing the measure is that the result depends upon the questions asked. If you were to ask people in the community 'Do you want better laws?' they would say yes. If you asked people 'Do you want fewer politicians?' they would probably say yes. If you asked people 'Do you want no politicians at all; would you prefer statesmen?' they would say yes. What is important is not the answer but the way in which the question is framed and, as well, the information that the electorate has before it in making up its mind and giving its answer. I would commend to anyone the excellent first report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. Perhaps if all of those who responded to the polls that Senator Baume and Senator Teague have been so determined to rely upon had had a chance to read that report first we would have had an informed response and I dare say that the result would have been vastly different from that quoted and relied upon as a superficial, off the cuff, easy option judgment.

As I have said, the electorate prefers statesmen to politicians and, if we are to presume to be in the first category and not the second, we ought to look at the issues and make our decisions according to logic. There are two key issues in terms of this legislation. The first is whether our representational task has changed and, if so, how. The second is the work test argument: Has our work load changed and, if so, how. Also, do both changes, taken together, justify an alteration in the number of parliamentarians to be elected to this place. I want to examine both issues but will start with that of the representational task because I believe that it is the more important. It is important for the fundamental reason that Parliament, as an institution, should always be, and remain, in touch with the common elector, not to be aloof, not to be a means of executive government rubber stamp. It should always be sensitive to the mood and feel of what ordinary Australians are concerned about. The important thing is that members of this Parliament, whether in the Senate or the House of Representatives, should be able to approach and talk with their own constituencies as local members.

For that reason I reject the suggestion that we should pursue the course that unfortunately has beset the United States of America, where one member of Congress represents 198,881 electors. It is argued by them that their task is made easier because of their huge support staff; that therefore they are able to get across the issues and communicate with their electorates. That means, though , that the member of the United States House of Representatives or Senate is much more remote as a person, much more aloof, much more unapproachable by the ordinary elector. There is a plethora of support staff between that member, he or she, and the community. Of course, politicians are like policemen: You do not particularly want to see them all of the time but when you need them they ought to be on tap straight away. The community has to battle through a front desk of support staff. That is one of the reasons politicians fall into disrepute; electors cannot have access when they need it. So I reject the course of maintaining our numbers as a small elite and adding additional support staff as it would keep us from having to confront the community on a personal basis.

The other risk that the United States course runs is that it puts government in the hands of experts who are not elected-the advisers to the members and those who are specialists in various areas-whereas, of course, the real theory should be that the experts should be on tap and not on top. Government should be run by the elected representatives, and not by the experts. Technocrats do not have a role when it comes to expressing the will of the community. Those of us who are elected as politicians should be in touch. To expand along the lines of the United States course, which opposition to this Bill fundamentally assumes is the course we should take, would be wrong.

Finally, I make the point in regard to the United States system that one must have great wealth to be elected. To cover an electorate of the size of one representative to 198,800 electors requires a huge investment by the individual member in campaign expenses, just to travel across that electorate. In the United States one tends to have to be wealthy to do that. Therefore, the possibility of a cross-representational group being elected to parliament from all walks of society is diminished to some extent. I think that the alternative pattern we should look at is really at the bottom of the theory behind this Bill . If we look at the United Kingdom and at Canada we find that in the United Kingdom, one representative represents 47,000 electors and in Canada, one representative represents 56,000 electors. Currently in Australia one representative represents 74,989 electors. This Bill will merely mean that one representative will represent 63,000 electors-still well ahead of the United Kingdom and Canada and, I think, still well enough in touch with the electorate, in terms of other needs, to keep parliament to a manageable size.

Figures show that, in my own State of Western Australia, the average divisional enrolment is 72,000 electors. This Bill will reduce that enrolment to 61,305 electors, assuming that it is carried and we have more parliamentary representation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a bit difficult to make those comparisons with the situation in Australia, as both Canada and Britain have appointed upper Houses.

—Yes, but that does not diminish the fact that nonetheless the role of those upper Houses is to represent the electorate and that the important fundamental point is that the electorate should have access to and control over electors. I think that if one takes those two factors together, the point is still sound and strong.

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the electorate of Kalgoorlie, if this Bill is not passed, a quite grotesque and unfortunate responsibility will be put upon the shoulders of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Graeme Campbell. At present, the Federal electorate of Kalgoorlie is 2,324,081 square kilometres in size-the biggest electorate in the world. Yet it is 863 under its quota. If there were a redistribution of electoral boundaries, the electorate of Kalgoorlie-gigantic though it is-would have to get bigger in order to be brought within the limits. So the task of representing that electorate would be made harder.

What this Bill would do in the case of Kalgoorlie and a number of other country electorates would be to make it easier for elected representatives from those areas to represent a more discernible and naturally geographical area and to enable representatives to cover great distances to be in closer contact with their own constituents. In 1949, when the last representation Bill was produced in this Parliament 39,000, nearly 40,000 electors, constituted the average size of an electorate. Today about 75,000 people constitute the average size of an electorate. As I have said, this Bill will bring that figure down to 63,000. In 1949, when the last representation Bill was before this chamber, the Liberals supported it. But since that time it looks as if that Party has lost its way and it has found alternative reasons to oppose the legislation.

My last reason for supporting this legislation, based on size, is that the principle of one vote one value-a fundamental principle of democracy-is more likely to be enshrined by the passage of this legislation than by its defeat. There will be less disparity between the size of Federal seats in the various States with the passage of this Bill. Therefore, in terms of the House of Representatives in particular, the important point of one vote one value is made .

I turn now to the other argument that I wish to put. The first point I made related to the size of electorates and the number of people we represent, and the second point I now wish to make relates to the work load of the Parliament. I think it is essential that there be retained a necessary tension between our duties in dealing with electors and our duties as legislators. That tension should always be one of competing demands. When we look at the increase in work in the Parliament we need go no further than the list of extra areas of involvement of Federal Parliament as set out on page 142 of the report of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform where 21 new areas are identified. At this stage I do not want to read out those 21 areas as they are on the public record. But any one of them is comprehensive and increasing in terms of its complexity. It is much more likely that, as we travel through time in the future , more areas will be added as life becomes exponentially more complex and, therefore, the work of representing the community and dealing with all those issues increases and becomes more difficult.

The number of senators and members to serve on all the committees established in this parliament is a matter of common remark. There are not enough. There are calls consistently for more committees to be established. I am certainly not one to complain; in fact, I take a great pride in the work load that I shoulder as a senator. I just turn as an example to my own case in which the issue of the work load can be best demonstrated. I stress that this is not a complaint; I simply refer to the privilege I have to be faced by further and additional challenges.

As a Senator in this place I joined the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. That Committee has a number of vitally important tasks before it. Also, when the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare took on board the issue of the retirement incomes inquiry, a matter of major concern and interest to me, I joined that Committee. It is conducting that vital and fundamental inquiry which will affect the lives of all Australians. Yesterday the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee had put before it an inquiry into the national crimes commission-another vital and fundamental concern facing all Australians. Both matters are important. Both matters have to be reported on in a limited time. Both matters require an immense amount of energy and attention. As I have said I do not complain about that; it is a privilege to have those challenges. But I make the point that all members and senators are in a situation similar to me in that respect.

In meeting those challenges and the extra work load we would be greatly assisted if there were more people in this place to shoulder those burdens and face the specialist responsibilities that are required of them. With a bigger parliament there is a greater chance for more speciality and a better quality of representation by the members. There is a chance, too, of a bigger pool of talent from which the Executive of the Parliament can be elected. That is important when one considers that the size of the Executive that grows commensurate with the increasing responsibilities placed upon the House and the necessary balance between the number of back benchers and the Executive to lessen the allegation of rule by Executive.

A number of speakers in this debate have concentrated on the possibility of a hung parliament and in particular a hung Senate. I do not think it is necessary to go into any other detail or to supplement the speech made by Senator Ray who, on this point, has provided a devastating argument that the allegations and fears that have been raised in debate are not justified. The possibility of a hung Senate increases with the composition we now have and by not supporting the Bill. On that basis and on the basis of my other remarks, I commend the Bill to the Senate and trust that my colleagues will see the wisdom of carrying it.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague has spoken of an opinion poll which was conducted in mid-October . A recent opinion poll was conducted earlier this month. The Hawke Government carries on and says that money is pretty short, that we are still in economic crisis, that wages have to be contained and that the unions must abide by the wages accord. Senator Baume referred to the fact that a financial impact statement had been promised to us by this Government shortly after the presentation of the Budget. No doubt the Australian Democrats believe-if I were one of them I would also believe this-that it is to their advantage to have control of the Senate. I do not think it is good for the country that a minority party-a small number of people-should have the final say over every piece of legislation that comes before us. I think the major party- whichever one happens to be in power-should have that advantage. But that is the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to rubber stamp the Senate as well?

—Senator Jack Evans has not been a senator for very long. He will find that on many occasions Liberal Party senators cross the floor. It has happened many times. He will find that there is no rubber stamp in this place as far as the Liberal Party and the National Party are concerned. I have crossed the floor and voted against my Government on several occasions, as all other Tasmanians have done. Therefore, we will not be a rubber stamp and cannot be accused of being a rubber stamp.
—When Labor is in power?

—Labor is a rubber stamp. Honourable senators must agree wholeheartedly that Labor senators are not part of the States House. As I said when I commenced my speech, the aim of Labor senators is to abolish the Senate. It is hypocritical of them to be members of this place when their main priority is to abolish the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the figures that are likely to result. As far as my State is concerned this would be disastrous legislation, and I shall tell the Senate why that is so. At the moment New South Wales has 43 seats, but under the new arrangements the number of seats in New South Wales will jump to 52. Presently Victoria has 33 seats, and under the new arrangements that number will jump to 39. At the moment those two big States alone have 76 seats, and that number will increase to 91. The number of Tasmanian seats, and it is the only State which will not have an increase, will stay at five. The new arrangements will make no difference to the number of Tasmanian seats in the House of Representatives; it will remain at five. The present situation is bad enough. The two big States completely swamp the small States by having 76 votes as against 49 in the House of Representatives. Under this legislation that disadvantage will increase because the combined vote of the two large States will be 91 and that of the small States and the Territories will be only 57. So an extra seven votes will go to the large States . That again, I believe, is a certain disadvantage.

Much has been said in this place today about the extra work load of the House of Representatives. Senator Cook has talked about Kalgoorlie being the biggest electorate in the world. It is, but it has a very small population. If his Party 's member of Parliament cannot cope he ought to give up his electorate. Our member of Parliament before the last election was coping perfectly well. If the Australian Labor Party's member cannot cope with Kalgoorlie he ought to give it up and hand it back to the Liberals, who were coping very well. It is quite incredible that Government senators tell us that their members cannot cope in their electorates. If they cannot cope they should not be holding them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to support the Representation Bill which provides for a long overdue increase in the size of the Federal Parliament. Section 24 of the Constitution provides that an increase in the size of the Senate must be the starting point for an increase in the size of Federal Parliament. It should be noted by all honourable senators that the Constitution clearly provides for an increase in the size of Parliament. When the founding fathers drafted the Constitution at the turn of the century they did not provide for fixed numbers over time. They made it very clear that it should be possible to change the number of people in the Federal Parliament, and this is what this Bill is about.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill stems from the work of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform. I would like to take the opportunity to congratulate that Committee on the fine work it did. The case for increasing the size of the Parliament, according to the Committee's report, was put to the Committee by a very prominent political scientist and also, I understand, by the New South Wales branch of the National Party of Australia. It was a majority recommendation of the Committee to increase the number of senators in each State from 10 to 12. I am very pleased to say that the Government accepted that recommendation. There are some very compelling arguments for an increase in the size of the Federal Parliament. The Joint Select Committee calculated that since the last increase in the size of the Federal Parliament in 1949 there had been an 87 per cent lift in average enrolments. That is an increase from 39,900 in 1949 to 74,900 in March of this year. I am now aware from figures published in October, that the average enrolment has gone over 75,000. So the 87 per cent increase in average enrolments since 1949 is a very large increase. That by itself suggests larger work loads and greater pressure on the electoral offices of members and senators .

I would like to make the point today that the enrolment growth figures understate the increase in the presssure developed by a growing population. What we should look at is the number of people in the Commonwealth rather than the number of electors, because from my experience and from the experience of many other members and senators a great number of the constituent cases which come into our offices are from people who are not on the electoral roll. In fact, a very striking figure can be calculated from the number of people coming into offices with constituent problems who are not enrolled to vote. If we actually look at the increase in the number of people in Australia since 1949 and try to pick up this factor of people who are not enrolled to vote, we get an increase of well over 90 per cent since 1949. It is noteworthy that those people who are not on the roll tend to have problems in regard to immigration policy or social security policy. We all know which government is responsible for those matters; it is the Federal Government. People come to see us about those problems.

It should be noted that the current proposal for an increase in the size of parliament is very modest. It provides for only a partial remedy to the change in the situation since 1949 and consequently will not return average enrolments to their 1949 level when the last change was made to the size of the Parliament. Over the last 30 to 40 years the Commonwealth Government has become much more active in a range of policy areas. The Commonwealth has drafted and passed much more legislation each year. More committees have been established in the Federal Parliament and more Ministers have been chosen to act as Members of the Executive of this nation. The trend towards more committees is very much in evidence at Westminster. It is a trend which is developing in parliaments around the world. Servicing the committee system really requires a large enough pool of members to staff those committees and to make sure that more expert decisions are made.

We have many more committees in Canberra now than we had in 1949. By the same token, the pool of members and senators available for committee work has been reduced somewhat by the lift in the size of the Ministry and the shadow Ministry . It is interesting to note that since the last Chifley Ministry in the 1940s, the size of the Ministry has increased by 70 per cent. The size of Parliament has been fixed over that period while the size of the Executive has increased by 70 per cent. I think it is quite possible to come to the conclusion that the balance between the Parliament and the Executive has been altered over that period.

I think some people would argue that Parliament's independence in relation to the Executive has suffered as a consequence. I believe that the availability of more back benchers and more talented back benchers would strengthen the position of Parliament versus the Executive. I think one of the important factors that has not been looked at in this debate is that the availability of more back benchers could mean more subject specialists. I think subject specialists are desperately needed in the Federal Parliament. There are too few at present. Amateurs certainly have their place in Parliament, but we really need people who are more expert in particular subjects so that they can monitor the work of the Executive more closely.

Since the last increase in the size of the Federal Parliament, the Federal Government has taken on many new responsibilities. For example, regulation of the national economy is something which has developed over that period. The Government has taken on what is called the stabilisation function which basically requires it to take fiscal and monetary actions to regulate the level of economic activity. That was an out-growth of a very famous White Paper in the 1940s and it has led to an enormous work load on the Federal Parliament. The welfare state has developed somewhat since the 1940s following the major referendum in that decade which conferred extra social security responsibilities on the Federal Parliament. We also see a Federal Parliament which is now involved in almost totally new areas such as family law and the environment, areas in which it was not involved in the 1940s when the Parliament was last inreased in size.

I believe that the increase in the size of Parliament will mean that members of parliament will be more accessible to their constituents. I think that the increase in the size of Parliament should help maintain rural representation here. In the case of an ordinary redistribution of electorates, it is quite conceivable that the rural area could lose seats. I think, importantly, those in the large area electorates will benefit. I am talking about seats like Kalgoorlie, Grey, Leichhardt and so forth. I think that the effect of the proposal to increase the size of the House will mean that those seats will not keep on increasing in size to ever greater and greater levels. In my State of South Australia, the seat of Grey currently accounts for some 90 per cent of the area of South Australia. I think a much larger area, following an ordinary redistribution, could mean a much harder job for the MP in that district. It would mean that the MP's constituents would also see him somewhat less.

Do not let us forget that since the 1940s, not only has the work load of members of the House of Representatives increased, but also the work of senators has increased with the increase in population. The proposal to increase the size of the Senate should mean that in a six-vacancy situation for a half-Senate election there should be more stability in government. Mathematically, it seems more likely that the party winning government will get at least three out of the six vacancies in a half-Senate election.

I am very pleased to note that my State of South Australia should benefit from this proposal. As of 31 October, the average enrolment in my State's Federal electorates was 79,700. That is the highest of any State or Territory and makes the average enrolment of my State some 4,000 above the national average. The proposal to increase the size of the Parliament should reduce the disparity between the average enrolment in South Australia and the national average. I hope that we can in fact move closer to the principle of one vote one value as a result of this change. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being near the hour of 12 noon, I shall call on Questions without Notice. Before calling anyone, however, I should mention that for purposes of Australian Broadcasting Corporation news broadcasts, I shall be lifting the Senate at one minute to one o'clock.

—Is the Minister for Industry and Commerce aware of reports concerning the introduction of a 38-hour week in the clothing industry early next year? Does he agree with industry projections that the cost of the 38-hour week, combined with national wage increases, will add over 12 per cent to the cost of production? Does he agree that wage increases and reduced hours can only lead to further loss of jobs and further tendency towards the use of outworkers and the sending of Australian jobs overseas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the proposed introduction of a 38-hour week in the industry to which Senator Chaney referred in 1984. I am not aware of any particular comment which suggests that the increase in cost to the industry of that projected change will be about 12 per cent.
—Ask Ray Aitchison. He will tell you.

—I am greatly indebted to Senator Peter Rae for his interjection. I have been meeting members of the textile, clothing and footwear industry this morning, and there was no projection put forward of anything like a cost of 12 per cent.
—Read the papers; I think that you will find that it is.

—They have had ample opportunity this morning to put that view to me, if it is their view. Certainly, I agree that the imposition of a 38-hour week will have an impact on the competitiveness of the textile, clothing and footwear industry in Australia, just as any wage increases under the centralised wage fixation system and indexation will have an effect on the competitiveness of those industries. As I have said in the Senate previously, however, these things are all matters for judgment. If the wages pause had been extended forever, by the year 2000 Australian industry might have been competitive with other industries in all respects, but that is not a consideration which this Government would take into account.

ANSWER.PARA: I make the point that the textile, clothing and footwear area is basically the last major industry area to introduce a 38-hour week. That is a factor which also has to be taken into account. In a telegram which I sent to the textile industry and other industries and the unions involved some months ago, I indicated clearly that insofar as the 38-hour week was concerned, the Government would expect offsetting productivity increases in return for the 38-hour week. That has been a subject of criticism from both sides of the industry. But in the course of negotiations, I think that some very significant offsetting productivity increase arrangements have been set in place in particular firms. I very much welcome that and encourage it.

Senator Hamer is not in the chamber at present, but he and I both visited a major factory in the textile industry in Australia, one to which Senator Peter Rae referred in another context last night, and I think that we both came away quite satisfied that significant changes have been made to work practices and so on which would improve productivity in exchange for the 38-hour week. That has been the Government's view. It is an important view. As I have said in another context which has been the subject of criticism, it is my own view that all these issues, including the issues of costs to an industry, have to be addressed in consultation between the various parties involved.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It refers to non-formal education for Aboriginals. Can the Minister say whether non-formal education is an effective development strategy particularly for Aboriginals living in rural and outback areas? Is the Minister able to advise whether it is likely that this type of education will be developed further, especially where the formal schooling systems have proved unsuccessful?

—I agree that non-formal education may have a role in the social and economic development of Aboriginal communities throughout Australia especially where such programs are developed as part of an overall educational and community development program. My colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Holding, advises me that there are institutions conducting courses of this nature with financial assistance made available through his Department. The continuation and possible extension of such assistance depends upon the demonstration by grant recipients that their programs are of direct benefit to the Aboriginal community and therefore justify a higher priority claim of Government funds than innovative and conventional education programs.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: OFFICE OF THE STATUS OF WOMEN

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. It relates to an extract from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet annual report 1982-83, published and circulated recently, entitled 'Office of the Status of Women-Activities of the Office 1982-83'. My question is on the section headed 'Register of Women for Government Appointment' which, in part, says:

QUESTION.PARA: Ministers will put forward names of men and women in equal numbers for government appointments, wherever possible.

. . . The Office of the Status of Women will assist ministers in identifying women suitable for nomination for such appointments, drawing on its register of women qualified to serve on government advisory bodies.

I ask the Minister: When was this register instituted? What does the term ' qualified to serve on government advisory bodies' mean, that is, what sort of qualifications are relevant? Are they professional, community or political involvement qualifications? Are specialised qualifications-for example, claimed professional qualifications-checked as to whether they are genuine? Who drew up the register, and from what sources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am surprised that Senator Martin is not familiar with the register, who is on it and how it operates, because it was instituted by the previous Government. It has been in operation for some years. I understand that, when it was first instituted, the Office of the Status of Women contacted women' s organisations widely throughout Australia and invited them to suggest women who would be appropriate for government appointment. I understand that it has also advertised over the years inviting suggestions of women who would be appropriately qualified and experienced to serve on government boards and authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: Since the change of government, the new Government has sought to have the register expanded by asking the Office of the Status of Women to go again to women's organisations asking for more names and some updating of information. The reason why we were anxious to have more names, of course, is that it is the policy of our Government to appoint wherever possible appropriately qualified women to boards and statutory authorities. At the last count, we had appointed approximately 30 women in that way. Ministers are not obliged to accept the advice of the Office of the Status of Women, but it is very useful for Ministers when seeking appointments to have available to them information from the register.

Senator Martin asked what sorts of qualifications are required. As honourable senators would be aware, the range of boards and statutory authorities to which the Commonwealth has the right of appointment is enormous. We have women who have qualifications in economics, small business, community work, community organisations, education, and so forth. On the list also are a very large number of women academics and women whose main contribution has been through voluntary organisations and so forth. The register, of course, would be available if Senator Martin would like to take advantage of this invitation to go and scrutinise it. It is information available to anybody.

Finally, I think Senator Martin concerned herself with how women got on to the register. I repeat the invitation to the Senate that any women's organisation, anybody who is aware of a woman who is appropriately qualified to serve on the vast range of boards and statutory bodies, may send in names and the Office of the Status of Women will add them to the register. As to whether the qualifications are suitable for any particular nomination, that, of course, is for the particular Minister making the nomination to find out. It is not possible for the Office to investigate the qualifications of every name which has come forward, but no Minister would put up names for appointment to a board or statutory authority, until he or she had satisfied himself or herself about the appropriateness of the person's qualifications and experience.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I think the Minister misunderstood one part of my question. I asked:

QUESTION.PARA: Are specialised qualifications-for example, claimed professional qualifications -checked as to whether they are genuine?

My reason for asking that is that governments have had previous experience of people allegedly having PhDs and being appointed to very high powered positions; later it has turned out that they did not have any qualifications at all. It was those sorts of qualifications which I was questioning.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to clarify that. I do not think the Office has the resources to check the claims to professional qualifications of every woman appearing on the register. If a Minister puts forward a name, nominates a person for a Cabinet or even a non-Cabinet appointment, it is the responsibility of that Minister to make the appropriate inquiries. Of course, as Senator Martin will be aware, when such appointments are made there are extensive inquiries as to the experience and qualifications of the persons involved. I do clarify the matter by saying that in my view it is the responsibility of the Minister making the nomination rather than the Office to carry out investigations into the authenticity of professional qualifications.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Given that Australian servicemen and women are and have been serving in a number of overseas peacekeeping forces, will the Minister advise whether there are any specific provisions under the Repatriation Act for these service personnel? If there are, will he advise me of those specific provisions and, if there are not, will he be introducing amendments to the Act to cater for them?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Members of peace- keeping forces do come within the provisions of the Repatriation Act. They are eligible for consideration under Division 10 of that Act. From time to time the Government does decide to commit Australian troops, male and female, to peacekeeping forces outside Australia; sometimes at the request of a particular country and at other times at the request of the United Nations. It appears that in those circumstances all such personnel are recognised by the Repatriation Act, as long as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, whose responsibility it is to make the decision, designates by notice in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette that such a group is participating as a peacekeeping force. In normal circumstances, persons involved in a war because of a decision of the Australian Government are automatically covered by the Repatriation Act but in respect of peacekeeping force personnel a specific decision of the Minister is required.

ANSWER.PARA: So, members of such forces are covered by the Repatriation Act for repatriation benefits from the moment of their departure from Australia until the moment of their arrival back in Australia. The Commonwealth is therefore liable to pay pensions in respect of incapacity or death that has arisen out of or is attributable to their service in that peacekeeping force. Of course that includes incapacity or death arising out of travel to or from that particular country. I am advised that Australian personnel are currently serving in a number of such multinational peacekpeing forces in the Sinai, Uganda, Kashmir and on the border of Syria and Lebanon. At the moment something like 120 personnel, mainly from the Royal Australian Air Force, based in the Sinai, are serving in such forces. I am further advised that those members of the Australian Federal Police serving in Cyprus are not covered by the Repatriation Act. I think that is a matter that the Government will have to examine.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Minister for Resources and Energy see the statements in the Australian Financial Review yesterday by the President of the Petroleum Exploration Society of Australia, Mr Ian Whiteley, that he believed oil shortages could occur as early as 1985-86, which is not very far off, prompting a sharp increase in what had been stable oil prices? The article states:

QUESTION.PARA: Mr Whiteley warned that world stockpiles of oil were likely to have fallen to the equivalent of only 50 days' consumption by the end of this year, compared to 65 days' in June and 115 days' at the end of 1981.
He regarded this as a potentially dangerous level of reserves, especially if there is a major conflict in the Middle East next year.

Again that background I ask the Minister: Why, in these circumstances, is the Government betraying the interests of Australians by selling our locally produced oil on the export market? Is the reason that the Government wishes to keep up its tax revenues? Will the Government reconsider the serious likely consequences of selling off our small and diminishing resources of a commodity, every litre of which will in future be vital to this country?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Mason has asked a number of questions. The answer to the first is yes, I did see Mr Whiteley's comments. Indeed, I answered a similar question yesterday on the same subject or arising from it.

ANSWER.PARA: To deal with the other points, the forecast that there would be a shortage of oil by 1985-86 is certainly not in accordance with the information which is available to the Government. I would go so far as to say that barring serious disruption to supplies caused either by political instability or by some natural disaster it is certainly not a realistic expectation that there will be world shortages at that time although, in the long term, one must expect real petroleum prices to increase. I am not able to confirm or deny whether world stocks have fallen from 65 days' supply in June to a forecast 50 at the end of this year.

The real point of Senator Mason's question was the Government's decision to permit, on a cargo by cargo basis, exports of Australian crude oil surplus to domestic refiners requirements. I take the point that he has put, that relative to other energy and mineral resources, Australia's reserves of oil are very limited. The logical extension of the argument which he has been putting would lead us to shut down production in Bass Strait and save all of the oil which is currently being produced and consumed within Australia for some time in the future because it would be possible at this stage to replace Australian crude entirely with imported crude. That is not an option which, as far as I know, anybody is seriously suggesting, but that is the logical extension and conclusion of Senator Mason's argument.

The principal reason that the Government made this decision to allow limited exports for the rest of this financial year and probably, I would expect, for succeeding years, is that present production potential is surplus, after the necessary technical and other minor adjustments have been made, to the demands of the domestic market.

TALK.START.PARA: —You could store it.

—We could store it, but it is an extremely expensive commodity to store, not only because of the cost of providing the tanks but also because of the capital which is tied up in the stocks which would be in the tanks if we decided to store it. I see little point, apart from holding necessary reserves for emergency, in pumping oil out of the ground and storing it in a tank on top of the ground if we have no intention of doing anything with it for a substantial period.

ANSWER.PARA: The most important factor influencing the Government's decision is that we do have surplus capacity right now. There are strong indications that that surplus capacity will inrease marginally or even substantially for some years into the future. If Australian producers or potential producers were in the situation in which existing production was locked in for lack of a market it is, I think, inarguable that that would have a very serious, even a devastating, effect on exploration activity. The Government is anxious to maintain high levels of exploration activity and sees the decision to allow limited exports of Australian oil as an important component of a package aimed at maintaining high levels of exploration activity.

Finally, to put it into perspective, the amount of crude which it is expected will be exported this year-I am going from memory here-is between 2 per cent and 3 per cent of total Australian production. So it ought to be seen as quite a small amount relative to total production but one which is, nevertheless, important because it provides the assurance which actual and potential producers need, that there will be a market for oil should it be discovered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, the Minister mentioned a point which prompts a supplementary question. I ask the Minister: Has he had the experience I have had of a number of people who are eminent in defence attributes of this country in fact putting forward the idea that at least some of the Bass Strait crude should be kept in the ground as a strategic resource?
—Order! That is not a supplementary question.
—The Minister raised the point himself, Mr President.

—I will allow it if the Minister is prepared to answer it, but it is stretching the long bow. A supplementary question is for the purpose of elucidating an answer. I thought Senator Walsh had done that amply.
—I concur, Mr President. I believe that Senator Mason's supplementary question, to the degree that it has relevance, has already been covered in the answer I have given.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs to newspaper reports which appear today indicating that the Commonwealth Schools Commission has released a report on computer education and that articles in the newspapers go on to discuss the content and implications of the report. Why has this report, available to journalists, not been made available to parliamentarians? Is she aware that the report is not available even now from the Senate Records Office and that it has not been tabled? Why have parliamentarians neither received nor had access to this important document here in the Parliament where a Bill presently before us asks us to approve the program which is the subject of the discussion paper? If it is not the intention of the Minister to treat the Parliament with contempt, will she ensure that significant papers of this kind from within her portfolio area are made available here in the Parliament as well as to journalists when they are released?

—The decision to publish the report was a decision of the Schools Commission. I do not know why it has not made it available to honourable senators. I hope that all honourable senators will address themselves to this report. It is a most important report because it deals with a very important innovation which the Commonwealth Government is funding. Senator Peter Baume is quite right to complain that parliamentarians ought to have access to it. I will make sure that this defect in the dissemination of the report is corrected as soon as possible and that Senator Baume has a copy of the report.
—And for the future, Minister.
—Senator Baume is giving me a little bit of advice across the table on how to manage these affairs. I will make sure that Senator Baume has a copy within the next hour.

—I have a supplementary question. I did ask the Minister whether she will ensure that in future important reports like this from within her portfolio are made available within the Parliament as well as to journalists .

—It is the desire of this Government to make as much information available as is possible, both to the public and to the Parliament. As Senator Peter Baume will be aware, we have a very difficult timetable situation on our hands. I will be seeking opportunities to table all reports. Another report in which Senator Baume will be interested is the participation and equity report. I will be seeking an opportunity to table that too. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Does the Minister recall an outrageous advertisement which appeared in the Tasmanian Press earlier this month in which over 100 medical practitioners indicated that they rejected the Medicare scheme? Is it also a fact that, either by legally binding arrangements imposed by the previous Government, such as on optometrists, or by virtue of the ethics of practice guidelines issued by associations of medical practitioners, medical practitioners and optometrists wishing to participate in the bulk billing arrangements under the Medicare scheme are prohibited from advertising that fact ? Will the Minister undertake such steps as are necessary to review the law and undertake discussions with associations of medical practitioners in order to ensure that those wishing to participate in the bulk billing arrangement under Medicare can inform potential patients of their desire to so participate?

—I do recall the advertisement to which Senator Tate refers. I think I made mention of it in the Senate a couple of times. I also am aware that there is an arrangement with optometrists-I understand that it arose out of a discussion between the optometrical association and the previous Government- whereby optometrists who bulk bill under the existing health scheme are unable to advertise that fact and are unable to notify their customers or potential patients of that situation. I can inform Senator Tate and the Senate that my colleague the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, is presently reviewing that situation. He is reviewing the need for optometrists or, indeed, other medical professionals to be deprived of the ability to let their potential patients know just what is the situation. As for the medical profession--
—It has nothing to do with the Commonwealth.

—I am sorry that Senator Walters is again demonstrating her ignorance. In the case of the optometrists it is to do with the Commonwealth. It was the result of an agreement between the previous Government and the optometrists.
—We are talking about the medical profession.

—I am now going to talk about the medical profession, if Senator Walters wondered when I would deal with it. It is true that under the etiquette- not the ethics-of the medical profession, medical practitioners are not supposed to advertise. However, in recent times a double standard has developed. It is perfectly legal for medical practitioners, like the group of medical practitioners in Tasmania recently, to advertise very widely in the Press that they will not bulk bill and that they will not have anything to do with patients who want to be bulk billed provided they put it into an advertisement getting stuck into the Labor Government, Medicare or the Department of Health. If, on the other hand, another doctor wants to advertise in the Press that he bulk bills and that he will give this service to his patients, he is not allowed to do so under pain of the disapproval or worse of the Australian Medical Association or his profession.
—What hypocrisy.

—That is hypocrisy, as Senator Walsh has said. It is a double standard. It is typical of one small section of the medical establishment and it is a matter that I will draw to the attention of the Minister of Health.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. On Wednesday in Question Time the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: I will seek information to see whether I can confirm that.

The confirmation referred to the situation that next year not just the 41 schools on the hit list but all group 1 schools and all group 2 schools will receive less financial support than they would have received under the percentage link formula. Will she now agree that those fee rises will be much greater next year in New South Wales and Victoria than she outlined on account of the New South Wales Government freezing the money amount going to non-government schools and the Victorian Government severely cutting such grants, in some cases by more than half?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have available the detailed information that Senator Teague was seeking about the group 1 schools other than the 41 about which there has been so much discussion. Apart from the 41 schools that received a small reduction in their Commonwealth grant, that is a reduction of 25 per cent, under our needs policy schools in group 1 will receive $10 less at primary level and $6 less at secondary level than they would have received under the percentage link formula. Schools in group 2 will receive $8 less at primary level and the same at secondary level under the needs policy. As the majority of students-60 per cent- in group 2 are at the secondary level, there has been no decrease in the grants attracted by the majority of students in group 2.

ANSWER.PARA: Schools in group 3 will receive $2 more at primary level and $21 more at secondary level under our needs policy than they would have received under the percentage link formula. What this means, for Senator Teague's information, is that 85 per cent of non-government schools, that is, 1,870 out of 2,220, will be better off under our needs policy than they would have been under the previous Government's percentage link formula. The matters that Senator Teague raised concerning decisions made by the governments of New South Wales and Victoria are appropriately addressed to those governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Do the Minister's figures confirm that all group 1 and all group 2 schools will be worse off than they would have been under the percentage link formula?
—Order! That is not a supplementary question.

—It is very difficult when I spell out the decisions with such clarity and then Senator Teague still has to to ask. The schools in group 1 get less than they would have got under the percentage link formula. About schools in group 2 I said this: The majority of students, that is, 60 per cent, in group 2 are at secondary level, where there has been no decrease in the grants attracted by the majority of students in group 2.
