I repeat that the majority of schools in the non-government schools sector are much better off under our formula, which is a needs based formula, which Senator Teague agrees with, than they would have been.
—I point out that five questions have been asked by the Opposition today and there have been four supplementary questions. It is making it difficult to give a fair call to everyone in the Senate.

—I refer the Attorney- General to the question that I asked him on 21 September about the Northern Territory Criminal Code. His reply to that question indicated that he was aware of the objections that had been voiced to the Code and that he was having it fully examined and analysed. I now ask the Attorney whether he can indicate what progress has been made with that examination and what further steps he proposes to take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case, as I have indicated previously to the Senate, that the new Northern Territory Criminal Code, which was assented to on 4 October and is proposed to come into effect from 1 January, has attracted numerous representations and complaints, addressed to both the Northern Territory Government, of course, and this Government. As I previously indicated, these representations and the Code itself have accordingly been subjected to very close study by the Commonwealth Government in order to see what encouragement we might be able to give the Northern Territory government to make appropriate amendments. That study has included a visit to the Northern Territory by a senior officer of my Department and a number of consultations with officers of the Northern Territory Government on the question. As a result of that study of the Code, yesterday the Prime Minister wrote to Mr Everingham as the responsible Northern Territory Minister, requesting that he reconsider a number of aspects of the Code with a view to possible amendment of it.

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister's letter made it clear that it was accepted that not only had most aspects of the Code given rise to no expressions of concern but also it contains many provisions which have been recognised widely and properly as working substantial improvements in the law. The Prime Minister's letter also acknowledges that a number of complaints about the provisions of the Code have been found upon examination to quite lack substance. However, the letter does go on to draw attention to six particular matters which do appear, at least on the face of it, to justify some of the concern expressed. These matters are: The intoxication provisions reversing the traditional onus of proof; the provision that intoxication is to be regarded in certain circumstances as a ground of aggravation of an offence, to be reflected in a substantially increased penalty; the abolition of unsworn statements from the dock which, although it might be defensible in principle, generally does raise some very acute issues so far as the Aboriginal community of the Northern Territory is concerned; the creation of mandatory life sentences for murder; the creation of an offence of attempted suicide; and also the provisions relating to terrorism and proscribed organisations. Mr Hawke's letter concludes by saying that he hopes it may be possible for Mr Everingham's Government-should it of course be around long enough to do anything in this respect-to give further consideration to the matters outlined and to amend the Code accordingly. He indicates that he is looking forward to receiving Mr Everingham's views. It might assist the convenience of those honourable senators who are interested in the matter if I were to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the full text of the Prime Minister 's letter, which I understand has now been received by Mr Everingham. I seek leave accordingly.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
PRIME MINISTER CANBERRA
17 November 1983
The Hon P. A. E. Everingham MLA
Chief Minister of the Northern Territory
Parliament House
Darwin NT 5790
Dear Chief Minister,
I refer to previous communications between you and the Commonwealth Attorney- General in relation to the Northern Territory Criminal Code 1983, assented to by the Administrator on 4 October 1983.

The Federal Government has received numerous representations about aspects of the Code. These representations have in the main, but by no means exclusively, been made by people of the Aboriginal community or their representatives, no doubt in recognition of the powers of the Federal Parliament pursuant to s.51 ( 26) of the Constitution to make laws with respect to the people of any race for whom it is deemed necessary to make special laws.

My Government's attention has also been drawn to published criticism of provisions of the Code by lawyers' and civil liberty organisations. On 2 November 1983, the Attorney-General was asked a question on notice by Senator Chipp requesting what action, if any, the Government intends to take.

Finally, I have also been advised that the Australian Law Reform Commission has recently written to you setting out provisional conclusions in its Evidence and Aboriginal Customary Law References which are inconsistent with provisions of the Code.
In all the circumstances I thought it appropriate to write to you requesting that your Government reconsider certain aspects of the Code before it comes into operation on 1 January.

At the outset I should make it clear that I readily accept that not only have most aspects of the Code given rise to no expressions of concern, but that it contains many provisions which have been recognised as working substantial improvements in the law: examples include the clarification of the defence of duress, the ''defence'' of coercion which can reduce murder to manslaughter, the extension of provocation to offences involving property, and the marital rape exclusion. I also note that section 31 imposes a heavier burden on the Crown in respect to criminal intention in that, except where intoxication is involved, the Crown must prove actual intent or, failing that, actual foreseeability of the consequences: if the Crown fails to prove the former but establishes the latter it must further prove that a reasonable person in a similar circumstance and having such foresight would not have run the risk involved.

I also readily acknowledge that a number of complaints about the provisions of the Code have been found upon examination to lack substance. For example, it has been claimed that drunken driving causing death could lead to conviction for murder. I agree that, provided the Courts interpret the Code in accordance with the publicly expressed intentions of the draftsman, this would not be the case. (It may, however, have been preferable to explicitly exclude the offences created by section 154 from the operation of paragraphs 162 (1) (b) and 162 (2) (a) in order not to leave something of such fundamental importance as a matter of statutory construction).

On the other hand, there are a number of aspects of the Code which clearly continue to give concern. These have now been discussed at some length, pursuant to an invitation extended by you, by Mr Woltring of the Attorney-General's Department with Messrs Sturgess QC and Conron.
As a result of those discussions, I am advised that further consideration was to be given by your Government to the three following matters:

(a) acquittal on grounds of voluntary intoxication followed by punishment and possible incarceration arising from section 383 (consideration was to be given to the deletion of the expression ''to pay by way of fine'' and the repeal of sub-section (3));
(b) the mandatory life sentence for murder in cases where the convicted person is other than an adult; and
(c) the 'sexual instincts' provision, insofar as it permits re-incarceration-as a person incapable of controlling his sexual instincts-merely for failure to notify address and occupation.
I would be pleased if you could advise me as to what progress has been made in accommodating these concerns.
Other matters discussed were not resolved, and it is particularly in respect of those matters that I now write to you. They fall into one or more of the following categories:
matters which may involve breaches of Australia's international obligations;
matters which appear to adversely, and possibly unfairly, affect the Aboriginal community;
matters significantly limiting individual rights in a manner inconsistent with current legislative trends; and
matters which may be thought more appropriately dealt with by Commonwealth law.
(1) Intoxication-Reversal of Onus
Section 7 of the Code appears to involve not only a departure from established legal principles but may amount to a breach of Australia's international obligations. It is in the following terms:
In all cases where intoxication may be regarded for the purposes of determining whether a person is guilty or not guilty of an offence, until the contrary is proved, it shall be presumed that-
(a) the intoxication was voluntary; and
(b) unless the intoxication was voluntary, the accused person foresaw the natural and probable consequences of his conduct and intended them.

The doctrine espoused in sub-section 7 (b) has never been part of the criminal law in Australia. Indeed, the adoption of it in England led to the earliest statement of the High Court that it could not and would not follow a House of Lords decision. In Parker v. The Queen (1963) 111 CLR 620 at 632 Dixon CJ said as follows:

In Stapleton v. The Queen we said: 'The introduction of the maxim or statement that a man is presumed to intend the reasonable consequences of his act is seldom helpful and always dangerous'. That was some years before the decision in Director of Public Prosecutions v. Smith, which seems only too unfortunately to confirm the observation. I say too unfortunately for I think it forces a critical situation in our (Dominion) in relation to the judicial authority as precedents of decisions in England. Hitherto I have thought that we ought to follow decisions of the House of Lords, at the expense of our own opinions and cases decided here, but having carefully studied Smith's Case I think that we cannot adhere to that view or policy. There are propositions laid down in the judgment which I believe to be misconceived and wrong. They are fundamental and they are propositions which I would never bring myself to accept. I shall not discuss the case. There has been enough discussion and, perhaps I may add, explanation, to make it unnecessary to go over the ground once more. I do not think that this present case really involves any of the so-called presumptions but I do think that the summing-up drew the topic into the mater even if somewhat unnecessarily and therefore if I left it on one side some misunderstanding might arise. I wish there to be no misunderstanding on the subject. I shall not depart from the law on the matter as we had long since laid it down in this Court and I think Smith's Case should not be used as authority in Australia at all.
I am authorised by all the other members of the High Court to say that they share the views expressed in the foregoing paragraph.

The High Court has adhered to this view and, in 1980, in R v. O'Connor 29 ALR 449, it held that an intent to do the physical act involved in a crime is indispensable to criminal responsibility and that acts the subject of a criminal charge must be voluntary in the sense that they be acts done pursuant to an exercise of the will of the accused. These were matters which the prosecution had to establish on the criminal standard of proof.

The reversal of onus in respect of an essential ingredient of a criminal offence places an insuperable burden on an accused to prove that he did not foresee nor intend the natural consequences of his conduct in circumstances where, for example, he has absolutely no recollection of the events leading to his arrest.

Additionally the presumption created applied to 'all cases where intoxication may be regarded for the purposes of determining whether a person is guilty or not guilty . . .'. Thus it could apply to an accused even though the reason why he may not have intended the act, or the applicability of some other defence, may be independent of the intoxication. For example, a mentally defective drunk will be presumed to have normal mental capacity.

The effect of the presumption and the persuasive onus cast on the defendant is that, providing all other elements of the offence have been proved, the prosecution need establish the criminal intent or mens rea only on the civil standard of proof.

In my view, this involves a radical departure from accepted criminal law standards and has serious implications for the precept that the innocent should be exposed to conviction. It also has serious implications in relation to the presumption of innocence and fair trial guaranteed by Article 14 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.
(2) Intoxication-Aggravation of Penalty

Whilst I appreciate that your Government is anxious to curb alcohol abuse in the Northern Territory, there would appear to be a case for suggesting that the approach taken in section 154-which adds substantially to the penalties applicable for dangerous acts or omissions where the defendant is intoxicated at the time-does not appropriately address the real problem so far as Aboriginal people are concerned.

In this regard I draw your attention to the words of Muirhead J, an experienced Territorial judge, in R v. Douglas Wheeler Jabanunga (Unreported, Northern Territory Supreme Court, 16 October 1980, transcript pages 27-9):

(T)he courts cannot effect a cure or diminution of the incidence of alcohol induced violence, but the situation cries out for community concern, intelligently planned programs and action rather than words. All the courts can do in the meantime is to punish those who kill or injure, but the deterrent value of what we do is, I am afraid, precisely nil.
The Australian Law Reform Commission appears to have adopted the same view in its Aboriginal Customary Law Research Paper 6 where, at page 99, it states:

One thing however is clear. Despite recent moves in this direction, the more vigorous application of legal penalties for drunkenness is practically certain to be ineffective, resulting only in more and longer terms of imprisonment for offenders whose real problems remain unaddressed, and without any element of general deterrence.
I would also draw to your attention the words of Forster CJ in the trial of an Aboriginal person, Ronnie Roebin Kamaranga, as recently as 16 September 1983:

I mean these people will continue to drink too much, a lot of them, so long as their life is full of despair and futility . . . that's the basic tragedy of the whole thing. A tremendous lot of white European people drink too much too but they haven't got the same almost overpowering motives to make themselves insensible as Aboriginal people have. As you know, and I've said it often over the years, and it hasn't fallen on very receptive ears, but I regard drunkenness as being a considerable mitigating factor of black people, although what the new Criminal Code is going to do to this I don't know.
I believe these views demonstrate that the approach adopted in the Code may be incapable of achieving the stated objective of your Government.
(3) Abolition of Dock Statement

Section 360 abolishes the right of any accused person, whether Aboriginal or European, to make a dock statement. Whilst I concede that the original reason for retaining dock statements may no longer exist in many societies, abolition of dock statements would appear to have the potential to operate harshly against Aboriginal people generally and tradition-oriented Aboriginal people in particular.

The problem is best demonstrated by the judgment of Forster J (as he then was) in R v. Anunga (1976) 11 ALR 412. (Forster J indicated that he was authorised to state that Muirhead and Ward JJ agreed). He stated:

I preface this statement of guidelines by pointing out that Aboriginal people often do not understand English very well and that, even if they do understand the words, they may not understand the concepts which English phrases and sentences express. Even with the use of interpreters this problem is by no means solved. Police and legal English sometimes is not translatable into the Aborifinal languages at all and there are no separate Aboriginal words for some simple words like ''in'', ''at'', ''on'', ''by'', ''with'' or ''over'', these being suffixes added to the word they qualify. Some words may translate literally into Aboriginal language but mean something different. ''Did you go into the house?'' means to an English-speaking person, ''Did you go into the building?'', but to an Aboriginal it may also mean, ''Did you go within the fence surrounding the house?''. English concepts of time, number and distance are imperfectly understood, if at all, by Aboriginal people, many of the more primitive of whom cannot tell the time by a clock. One frequently hears the answer ''Long time'', which depending on the context may be minutes, hours, days , weeks or years. In case I may be misunderstood, I would also emphasise that I am not expressing the view that Aboriginal people are any less intelligent than white people but simply that their concepts of certain things and the terms in which they are expressed may be wholly different to those of white people.

Another matter which needs to be understood is that most Aboriginal people are basically courteous and polite and will answer questions by white people in the way in which they think the questioner wants. Even if they are not courteous and polite there is the same reaction when they are dealing with an authority figure such as a policeman. Indeed, their action is probably a combination of natural politeness and their attitude to someone in authority. Some Aboriginal people find the standard caution quite bewildering, even if they understand that they do not have to answer questions, because, if they do not have to answer questions, then why are the questions being asked?
As can be noted from His Honour's remarks, even the services of an interpreter may not solve the problem.

Again, the Australian Law Reform Commission appears to have reached a similar conclusion at page 69 of Research Paper 13 entitled ''Aboriginal Customary Law Problems of Evidence and Procedure''. At page 69 it states:

What can be said is that the difficulties in giving evidence experienced by many Aborigines, as well as others with problems of illiteracy and poor comprehension of English, are powerful reasons for not abolishing the right to make an unsworn statement. In particular, it is regrettable the the Northern Territory, where these problems occur with some frequency, proposes to abolish unsworn statements in its new Criminal Code.

It would appear that, at least in respect of Aboriginal persons, the abolition of the right to make a dock statement has potential for infringing the cardinal precept of our legal tradition, namely that the risk of convicting the innocent must be obviated.
(4) Mandatory Life Sentence

As a general rule, the imposition of a mandatory life sentence for murder would appear to run counter to current trends. For example, the ACT does not have a mandatory life sentence for murder and it was abolished in New South Wales in 1982. Other jurisdictions, I am advised, have the matter under consideration.

There is the additional problem that some Aboriginal persons may be convicted of murder in circumstances where there may be a tribal or customary basis for the act, but that same tribal or customary law precludes revelation of it. Had the true facts been known, the person may have been either charged with or convicted of manslaughter.

Whilst I appreciate that Territory law presently requires the imposition of a mandatory life sentence for murder where the convicted person is other than an Aborigine, the extension of it to Aboriginal persons is perceived to be a retrograde step.
(5) Attempted Suicide

The creation of the offence of attempted suicide carrying a penalty of imprisonment for one year is seen as another regressive step. In the view of many it is an attempt to make the subject of criminal law a medical problem.

I am aware that the justification put forward for the creation of the offence is that it attracts police powers of entry and apprehension in would-be suicide cases, and that it is not intended to prosecute such persons.

It would seem that a more presentable manner of achieving this object would be to either expressly confer such a power on the police in such cases or, alternatively, to deal with such cases under mental health legislation.
(6) Terrorism and Proscribed Organisations

Whilst conceding that terrorist acts can amount to offences against State or Territory laws (e.g. murder, abduction, malicious damage, extortion etc.) there is concern that the laws of the Commonwealth already cover areas included in the Code definition of ''act of terrorism''. Clearly any act against overseas and interstate aircraft, internationally protected persons and foreign governments should, in the eyes of the international community, be within the domain of Commonwealth law. Similar considerations apply to terrorism aimed at, for example, the overthrow of the Government or capable of affecting the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth or the sovereign integrity of the Commonwealth.
These areas are to be further examined during the major review of the Commonwealth Crimes Act which, as was announced recently, is to be conducted next year.
With respect to the provisions relating to proscribed organisations I note that , under section 51, the Administrator may make regulations proscribing an organisation which either:
(a) in the opinion of the Executive Council has as its objects the use of violence to achieve its ends; or
(b) the members of which, in the opinion of the Executive Council, have, in the Territory or elsewhere, demonstrated a propensity to use violence to achieve the organisation's ends.
'Propensity' means a likelihood or tendency, not a demonstrated past use coupled with reasonable grounds for believing a continued use of violence.

The Legislative Assembly may, by simple majority, approve the Regulation. The framers of the Code must have foreseen the potentially wide application of this section, as sub-clause 5 exempts registered trade unions.

Belonging to a proscribed organisation, soliciting financial or other support for it, knowingly making or receiving contributions to it, or arranging or addressing certain meetings of it, are all crimes carrying 2 years imprisonment.

It is only the opinion of the Executive Council, and the agreement of a simple majority of the Assembly, which is required before these consequences flow. There is no provision, for example, permitting an organisation to show cause why it should not be proscribed such as that in s.30AA of the Crimes Act 1914, where the Attorney-General may apply to a Court for an order that a body is an unlawful association.

Concerns have been expressed that this section has potential implications for interference with a number of civil rights, which Australia has international obligations to protect including the right to freedom of expression, the right to freedom of association and the right to peaceful assembly.
I hope that it may be possible for your Government to give further consideration to the matters outlined, and to amend the Code accordingly. I look forward to receiving your views.
Yours sincerely,
R. J. L. HAWKE

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce whether it is a fact that he has, as an apparently leaked report in the Australian Financial Review of 14 November indicates, concluded his long awaited restructuring of the industry advisory councils? Is this another example of the Government's much vaunted but not practised 'bringing Australia together'? Does Bob Hawke, the Prime Minister, support this divisive action by his Minister for Industry and Commerce? —A statement which appeared in the Australian Financial Review under the byline 'John Durie' reported on correspondence that I had had with various industry organisations relating to the establishment of industry advisory councils. I cannot say yes to the first question. The setting in train of those councils is well under hand-I mean in hand--
—I think you got it right the first time.

—Perhaps I am answering a later question. An announcement will be made when the membership of those councils is finalised. —Can the Minister for Resources and Energy inform the Senate of progress made in implementing the Australian Labor Party's 1983 election policy commitments towards the better management of the nation's water resources?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last year I think it was, Mr Jacobi, the honourable member for Hawker, who has shown a long-standing interest in this matter, introduced a private member's Bill to establish an Institute of Freshwater Studies. That was a major component of the election policy which the Labor Party put to the people in February and March this year. I am pleased to report that the Interim Council appointed to make recommendations on such an Institute was formally appointed about two weeks ago. The first meeting of the Council was held yesterday. That meeting continues today. The members of that Council are, I believe, a particularly prestigious group of people and well-equipped to discharge the task which the Government has given them.

ANSWER.PARA: The Chairman is Professor Quirk, Director of the Waite Agricultural Research Institute in Adelaide. Other members are: Professor Nancy Millis, Professor of Microbiology at the University of Melbourne, Dr R. J. Millington, Chief of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation Division of Water and Land Resources, Mr B. D. Scarsbrick, of the New South Wales Department of Agriculture and Fisheries who is Regional Director for the Murray and Riverina region, Mr K. J. Shepherd, Director of Water Resources for the Ministry of Water Resources and Water Supply in Victoria, Dr D. W. Connell, Reader in Environmental Chemistry, Griffith University and Dr B. R. Davidson, Senior Lecturer in Agricltural Economics at the University of Sydney. I have responded in general terms on behalf of the Government to that report that was tabled last week and drawn attention to the particular recommendations of that report with regard both to priorities for funding and areas of neglect in the past in water supplies in its various forms and to questions of pricing policy.

One of the points which that 'Water 2000' report highlighted was that the water supplies, in both quantity and quality, available to a great number of country towns, and in particular smaller country towns, were inadequate. The traditional methods of providing finance for water supplies have concentrated on other areas , to the detriment and exclusion of people who live in country towns, especially smaller country towns. That, I think, ought to be a matter of shame for the National Party, which has governed federally for almost all of the last 34 years , for a good deal of that time in New South Wales and for the greater part of that time in Queensland. It ought to be a matter of shame for the National Party that it has neglected the very people it claims to represent. This Government has taken some steps towards rectifying that previous neglect with the allocation within the community employment program of $20m to improve the water supplies for admittedly what would have to be a relatively small number of those country towns which have been so shamefully neglected for so many years by the people who claim to represent them.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Social Security been drawn to an article in the current edition of the Australian Pensioner headed ' Rift Over Age Care-Office is still only a promise'? Can he advise the Senate whether he agrees with the statement that the Office of Aged Care must be basically medical and health oriented? Finally, can he indicate to the Senate whether, as the shadow Minister claims, the Government is backing off in its commitment to establish the office?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure Senator Zakharov and the rest of the Senate that the Government has not backed off and is not backing off on its promise to establish an office of aged care. It is interesting to note that the shadow Minister for social security was formerly a member of governments in power for seven years and until 1972 for 23 years. They never established, or thought of establishing, an office of child care-I am sorry, office of aged care.
—Either.

—Yes, either. It is interesting to note that the shadow Minister should come into this place and complain bitterly that this Government, after eight months in power, has not established it. As I said in the Senate last week or the week before, there will be an office of aged care. There is no rift between Government members on this matter. The Government Ministers agree that there shall be an office of aged care. Dr Blewett and I are in agreement that it should be so. Dr Blewett's involvement in the development of the frail aged policy of the Australian Labor Party for many years before the last election makes it appropriate that he, as much as anybody else, including me, should be the ministerial administrator of such an office. There will be an office of aged care. The announcement about the administrative arrangements of that office will be made in the next few weeks. No Government decision has been made to put this matter on the back burner. We will be investigating the general arrangements in the welfare and health area before we make our decision. We do not want to make them hastily.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, yes, I did notice the statement in the Australian Pensioner that an office of aged care 'must be basically medical and health oriented'. That quote is attributed to Dr Anna Howe who is well known to some people in this place and who has a very specific view on the care of the aged. It is not a view I agree with. It is not a view that is agreed with by the vast majority of people involved in aged care in this community. By and large, the aged, even the frail aged, do not have as their basic problem the fact that they are sick. They have many problems and those problems should be looked after by the community and under the direction, or with the assistance, of a multi-disciplinary team. I believe there is no reason why that team, of necessity, should be composed of doctors although one would certainly, I dare say, include a geriatrician in any assessment team. I do not believe, and I do not believe that the majority of people in the community believe, that aged care is basically a medical and health problem to be solved by a medical and health oriented health program. I do not believe Dr Blewett or anyone in this Government believes that. This is the view of Dr Howe which is not widely shared within the community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: -Before the debate was interrupted I made the point that the Representation Bill currently before Parliament will reduce average enrolments in the South Australian divisions to a figure much closer to the national average. It will help to increase the value of the votes of the electors of my State which have been relatively undervalued in recent years by the current distribution. In 1949 when the Parliament was last increased it was acceptable to reduce enrolments in Federal divisions from around 65,500 to 39,900. In 1983 it should be acceptable to cut the average enrolment from 74,900 by a smaller amount to 64,000. It is striking that the proposed new average enrolments in Federal divisions are virtually the same as those which were regarded as unacceptably high before the redistribution in 1949 . Both averages are in the range of 64,000 to 65,000. If it was appropriate then to reduce the size of electorates, I believe it is appropriate now.

SPEECH.PARA: The report produced by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform was first class. This Bill is timely. The reforms that will be set in train will represent a watershed in Australian political history. I believe honourable senators should consider the real question of whether we want members of parliament and senators to carry out adequately their two major tasks; that is, to represent the people and to contribute to national policy formulation. I believe the Bill will enable members of parliament and senators better to carry out those two major responsibilities, and for that reason the Bill should be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Representation Bill which provides for an increase in the size of the Parliament; that is, an increase of 12 senators and 24 members of the House of Representatives. As is known, the Opposition opposes this Bill. My reasons for opposing this Bill are somewhat different from those of a number of my colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: Over the years I have been known to favour very strongly an increase in the Parliament, and I still do. I still think that now is an appropriate time to increase the Parliament. But there are factors in this Bill which I think have been greatly underconsidered by the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and which, I am afraid, would lead to a highly unfavourable result for the continued existence of the Senate if the legislation were passed in its present form.
We have to face the fact that there is a populist argument against increasing the number of members of parliament. I do not hold or support that argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think arguments apply equally to both chambers?

—My criticisms apply more to the Senate. I believe there is a case for an increase in both Houses of the Parliament, but the results will be felt most disastrously in the Senate. It is easy to say that members of the public show by polls that they do not like increases in the number of members of parliament. Any poll dealing with members of parliament and politicians produces an automatic result, and this is the success of the media over the years.
—It has grown fourfold since 1949.

—Yes, I noted that point when the honourable senator made it. I think it is significant that the size of the media reporting the Parliament has increased fourfold, but members of the media will very rapidly say that there is no need for any change in the number of members of parliament, not noticing the incongruity of their argument. The media thrives upon attacking members of parliament, reporting trivia and sometimes somewhat disgraceful behaviour by some members, but ignoring those occasions when the chamber is in agreement on any matter and failing to report substantially anything good that comes out of this Parliament. Therefore they have injected a prejudice in the public that anything that might improve the working conditions of politicians is to be opposed.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer now to one of the arguments that have been put in this debate; namely, that we should try again to get rid of the nexus so that we can increase the size of the House of Representatives without increasing the size of the Senate. I leave aside the fact that I think there is a stronger case for increasing the size of the Senate than for increasing the size of the House of Representatives. It is my belief that because of the tremendous work which this chamber does and which the other chamber does not do in regard to committees and the fact that we are finding it impossible to cope and there is a risk of breakdown in this area, there is a strong case for increasing the size of both chambers. I leave that aside for the moment. The proposition to break the nexus was defeated when it was put to the people some years ago because a couple of senators and a few others managed to persuade the people that this would lead to our having many more members of parliament. I think it was a completely illogical argument but it was enough to persuade the public, against the opinions of all the major parties, to reject the removal of that nexus. The reason is the constitutional requirement that the numbers in the House of Representatives be twice those in the Senate and which limits, therefore, the way in which we can increase the size of the Parliament.

I am quite sure that if we again put that proposition to get rid of the nexus the same argument would arise. A number of State politicians and others would join in the fun and games. Of course, there is something in that argument because if we had no nexus we could increase the size of the House of Representatives by a few members one year and a few more in the future. We would not be limited to having to comply with the necessity of increasing the size of the Senate by, say, twelve, which would make for a fairly substantial increase in the size of the House of Representatives, which must be double the size of the Senate.

We should put aside the general populist argument, which is always to be found, that politicians should not be paid anything; they are a lot of no-goods and they do no work. The fact that we may work perhaps 60 or 70 hours a week, which I think would be a fair average for members of both chambers, would be totally ignored and probably disbelieved by the public. Members of the public, with their fight for a 38-hour week and so forth, would find it impossible to understand that most members of parliament work jolly hard and find it impossible under current conditions to cope with all the changes that are made.

I heard the speech of Senator Robert Ray. I compliment him on the activity and interest he has taken in electoral matters both in the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and in his speech today. I find myself in substantial agreement with many of the matters that he brought before the chamber. He set out the changes in the duties of MPs and senators over the years and the number of major areas of policy in which we are supposed to be expert and in which very often we cannot be expert.

I do not think the comparisons that are made and have been made in this chamber with the United States Congress are particularly useful. I have visited the United States of America and talked to senators and members of the House of Representatives there. In effect they are highly divorced from the people of the United States. They are really departmental heads. They have staffs of up to 80 or 90 people. The result is that they do not read their own mail. In fact, while I was in the United States in recent years one of the legislative assistants to a senator told me in a scandalised voice that he had caught his senator reading some of his constituents' mail. I said: 'I read all my constituents' mail'. He said that United States senators did not read their own mail but that the mail was divided amongst various groups of staff and dealt with in that way. Only the mail of very significant figures like judges and local politicians is read by the senators. Therefore, the senators in the United States who represent a lot more people do so with an excessive number of staff, in my opinion, and they are very much divorced from the people. A better comparison, I think, is to be found in Canada, which has a bigger House.

The case for the increase in the Senate and in the House of Representatives is quite considerable and must be based not only upon the change in demands and requirements of members of parliament but, more importantly, on the fact that in Australia, with such a small Parliament, the executive dominates too much. I think that Senator Robert Ray mentioned the executive component on the Government side, but on the opposition side, which is always smaller than the Government side, the dominance is even greater. The fact is that the back bench needs to be larger. If we were to get 24 extra members in one House and 12 in the other we could expect to get a few resolute back benchers who would stand up to Executive dominance. I think that would be a real value of an increase.

I have read what the New South Wales Branch of the Institute of Public Affairs has claimed in its report on the proposed increase in the number of Federal parliamentarians. I regret to see that my good friend Mr Christopher Puplick, a former senator, is one of the people who contributed to that report and to a statement therein about a smaller increase in the Parliament. Speaking of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform which investigated this proposal, he said:
At no stage did any witness, nor did the Joint Committee itself express support for more Senators, and indeed there are no arguments which support this proposition.
That is an arrogant statement if ever I heard one. The report continues:
If then, the object of the exercise is to increase the size of the House, the logical solution would be to put the matter to the people via a referendum to do away with the nexus.

I have already said that it would be a forlorn task if one hoped to do it that way. There is a case, and the case has been put in this House, for an increase in the Senate. I believe that senators would be accommodated and would be able to do a great deal of extra work, some of which is not being done at the moment. As I have put it, I think that the great value of an increase lies in the removal of the Executive dominance or in a decline or watering down of that dominance, which we have seen occurring in recent years. We can hope that among the new members would be people who would be able to contribute in that regard. There is no doubt that a staff increase is not the answer. A staff increase is obviously necessary. It has been a screaming necessity for some years. That argument has been put up by the Remuneration Tribunal but so far it has been put aside by government after government.

One other argument which I think was mentioned by Senator Robert Ray this morning was that he doubted whether the new Parliament would accommodate, or whether plans had been made to accommodate, the increased number of members. Clearly, that is a misconception. As one who has served for eight years on the Joint Committee on the New and Permanent Parliament House, I can assure him that this matter was very much in mind. The new Parliament House is clearly capable of expansion. One only has to go up to the site now to see the House of Representatives chamber, which is taking real shape, and to see how easy it will be to put extra seats in the chamber. It was also clearly envisaged that extra rooms would be available for a bigger parliament. That was always in the contemplation of the parliamentary committee. It might be true that here in this Parliament House there might be some discomfort for a couple of years, but I think that would be less important than the value which would come from acceptance of this proposal.

It is never time to increase a parliament. That has been argued. Unfortunately, most of my Liberal colleagues on this side take the view that it is not the time . It never is the time. I regret that I cannot support this proposal because of another matter which was so completely overlooked by the committee of review, and that is that unless some change is made this proposal will lead automatically to six senators being elected for each state each time in the future. This would not apply in the first election after the Bill was passed, because seven senators have to be elected at that time in order to achieve the increased number. So in that election there will be an opportunity for a result, for a real contest to take place in the various States where one party which is more popular than another can get an increase. There might even be a result of four to two for the main Opposition and one Australian Democrat, but a majority is possible.

I have doubts about and must disagree with some of the things that Senator Teague said this morning. But I have the same opinion that in a six vacancy Senate election 57 per cent of the population in a State would have to vote for a party for that party to get a four to two majority. That has only happened once in recent memory, I think, in 1975 in Queensland. It is unlikely to happen with the fairly even nature of parliamentary parties. Senator Teague presented an argument on the basis that the Australian Labor Party has never got, or did not in recent elections, get 43 per cent of the primary vote. The important thing is, of course, that, when preferences are distributed, I have no doubt that both the major groupings, the Liberal and National parties on one side and the Labor Party on the other, would manage, in a six vacancy election, to get three senators and, in many cases, would crush out the Democrats. I have no doubt that this is one thing that persuades the Government to have this form of election for the Senate.

I believe that, unfortunately, the result of a six vacancy election will make, in most cases, the Senate elections in the various States a non-event. Perhaps the Senate might be then brought into some disrepute because of the unimportance of its election process. In speaking on the report, I have argued that this could be overcome by the election, in three States, of seven senators in any ordinary half-Senate election and five senators for the other three States. Then in the next three-year election the process could be reversed. Five could be elected from the three States and seven from the others. It has been questioned whether this proposal could be operated under the provisions of the Constitution because section 13 of the Constitution requires us, after a dissolution of the Senate, to create two sets of senators, one set continuing for a full six-year term, or eight-year term if that amendment is passed, and the other continuing for a three-year or four-year term. It requires that that division must be as near as practicable to an equal division of the number of senators from each State. I argue that any distribution that leads to a six vacancy election is one that is not practicable from the point of view of electing and decently upholding the position of the Senate in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —What you are saying is that this is a party House. You have finally admitted it.

—No. This is a party House, among other things. It is a House of review, it is a party House and, to some degree, it is a States House. It has all those features. We live in a situation where party government generally prevails in this country. I do not think there is any surprise about that. I believe that we need a situation whereby a government which is very popular has a small majority in the Senate. But I believe that when we have a seven vacancy election, after we get past the first election we will rapidly get ourselves to the position where perhaps the Labor Party will always have a blocking majority or blocking minority. It will have half the senators. By the time the opposing party, in government, has elected the President of the Senate-and it will have to have a majority to pass anything through the Senate-the Labor Party would be able to stop any legislation from being passed. If it wants to do something on a negative basis then it would have a negative blocking majority. But we on this side might also have the same thing.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that a government which has proved popular and been re-elected ought to be entitled to expect a small majority in the Senate and to get its legislation through without having to rely on others. On the other hand, if we have a six vacancy Senate election we will probably have what Senator Macklin was getting at this morning; that is, we will have a government that is not supported by a majority of the people having a veto on whatever the other parties want to do in the chamber. For example, no doubt the Democrats will be reduced very much in size and, with the other parties on this side of the House, there will be a situation where those parties, between them, may represent the majority of the people but they will not be able to get legislation through this chamber. The people who will finish up running this chamber will probably be Senator Harradine and perhaps Senator Chipp, if he survives in this process. I do not think that Houses which are dominated by one or two individuals are desirable and I think it is a very undemocratic process. I fear what will result by the Government not thinking through this proposal and not thinking through the proposal I made that we should have groups of sevens and fives and therefore get a result.

I know that Senator Evans, the Attorney-General, received an opinion-he supplied me with a copy of it-from an officer in his Department about whether my proposal was feasible. The officer mistook the first part of my proposal because he did not realise that I was not talking about the first election, which must be for seven senators anyway. However, thereafter he said in the opinion:

As you indicated, there is a problem with s.13. That provision requires that after a double dissolution 'the Senate shall divide the senators chosen for each State into two classes, as nearly equal in number as practicable'. In my view, any division of senators for a State into groups of 7 and 5 after a double dissolution would be inconsistent with this provision.

One would then expect he would go on to give reasons for that view, but unfortunately he does not do any such thing. It is just a sheer assertion on the part of some junior officer of the Attorney-General's Department that that is not the correct meaning. But if he is right, I think we will still have to come back to this problem. If this Bill goes through and we are stuck with the equal number of senators, within a few years we will have to come back to bring the Senate into some sensible voting system. We would then be able to put a constitutional amendment to the people. I have no doubt that, if faced with the choice not of increasing the Parliament or otherwise, because that would have long since been done, but of deciding whether they wanted a practical election that had a result in the Senate or would be content to just have the six all, the people would vote for that first alternative in the proposal which I put forward.

I believe it is a fundamental defect to this Bill that it will provide the Senate soon with a deadlock situation which will be quite disastrous for firm government in this country. It will put us and the government in the hands of one or two individuals who may delight in having that excessive power but it will not be a good thing for democracy in this country and it will not be majority rule in this country.

Because of that serious defect I therefore must vote against the Bill. I do it with great regret because of the fact that I think there is a good case for increasing the Parliament. I am sorry that the Attorney-General and his Department are so arrogant about this that they have not looked at any alternatives and have therefore been content to go along with it. I would even give them the benefit of the doubt that they did not intend to emasculate the Senate if I could see some evidence of it, but that will be the effect, in my opinion, if this legislation is allowed to continue. If it goes through we will have to come back to repair this situation after the event. True, there will be time to do that because there is first to be an election with seven and then, two or three years later, there is to be an election where the sixes would take place. So there would be time, and no doubt we will put constitutional amendments before the people in that period. I believe that, because of the inherent defect and the unthought-out nature of this proposal in its dealing and effect on the Senate, it must be opposed. For that reason I vote against the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In debating this proposal, the Representation Bill 1983, to increase the size of the Parliament-the House of Representatives and the Senate-it is entirely appropriate that we should spend some time discussing the effect of this proposal on the Senate. Senator Missen has, in his usual eloquent and well thought out way, put forward a very detailed argument in terms of what effect this proposal will have on the political realities of the Senate and how those political realities will overwhelm the opportunities the Senate has to carry out its duties. I will say a little later on a few more words on my views on this. I commend Senator Missen's speech to the members of the Government and hope that they give it the usual high regard that they give his speeches.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been an air of some unreality for me in listening to this debate today, here in a House of Parliament of which we are very proud. We are very proud of the fact that we have democratically elected assemblies and governments in this country and yet the very issues of democracy are ones that are not issues in this debate. I have found that air of unreality grow as I have heard Labor senators saying that one of the reasons we need more members of parliament is so that we can better serve the people. I think that Senator Maguire, a Labor senator from South Australia, actually said that one of our main tasks was to serve the wishes of the people and in describing our task he was giving that as justification for needing more members of parliament. It is the height of absurdity, if not of hypocrisy, on the part of the Labor Party to be advancing arguments such as that in the face of quite overwhelming popular opposition to the proposal.

There has been reference to some Morgan gallup polls during this debate today and reference to a gallup poll of a couple of months ago which showed that 76 per cent of Australians were opposed to an increase in the number of members of parliament. Later in the debate Senator Walters was good enough to outline to the Senate a more recent gallup poll than the poll to which the Press seems to refer all the time and that is one which was taken early this month, which showed, as I recall, that 83 per cent of people were opposed to an increase in the number of members of parliament. It is interesting that there is even that much shift, given that the position was so strong to start with. It has been in the last month that there has been so much public debate and awareness of the fact that the number of members of parliament is about to increase. So those who have advocated an increase in the number of members of parliament have obviously been abysmal failures in their attempt to persuade people that there is a need for more, because their best efforts have only managed to increase the percentage of people who are opposed to an increase in the number of members of Parliament.

There is a further element of unreality in the whole conduct of this debate. Here we have, throughout it, politicians telling the people that what the people really need is more politicians. But the essence of a democracy is supposed to be people telling politicians. I believe the people will tell the politicians when they want more politicians. That is about what it comes down to-politicians telling the people that they need more politicians. Senator Grimes smiles and shakes his head. It was a whimsical smile.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I ask you whether Senator Walters follows her dictum on such things as abortion law reform or other things? Is it not phoney to bring in that argument now?
—Senator Grimes should have asked that of Senator Walters while she was present.
—I was not present, unfortunately.
—I follow my own dictum.
—In other words, you only vote the way the polls go. You are putting yourself down.
—I have a rather out of date list of speakers here, Mr Deputy President. I do not see Senator Grimes's name on the list.
—I am asking you a question. You are putting yourself down.

—I see from the list that after I have finished speaking there are to be several Opposition speakers, but there are no further Government speakers until Senator Gareth Evans. There is room on the list for Senator Grimes. He is using my time to make his points. His speakers can make their points. He is very welcome to use his own time to make his points. That is what Parliament is about-debating the issues. But I intend to return to the point and to get on with the speech that I was making. We are under some constraints of time because we have been requested to reduce the length of our speeches. That is an additional reason why I am so reluctant to join with Senator Grimes in this very pleasant interchange.

SPEECH.PARA: I was saying that here we have politicians telling the people that what they need is more politicians. I have never had a complaint from a constituent to the effect that there are not enough politicians. I have never had a complaint from a constituent such as: 'By golly, I wish that there were more politicians that I could ring up or write letters to'. I have had complaints from people about difficulty in getting appointments because I spend so much time in Canberra and, these days, Fridays as well. I have some gripes myself about the difficulty of finding time. But I have never had someone say, when there has been difficulty in arranging an appointment, let us say, for today, at short notice, 'Oh Lord, if only there were more politicians then my problems would be fixed'-never.

TALK.START.PARA: —I expect that some say that they wish there were more like you.

—Frequently they make comments such as 'If only we had more politicians like you', but I do not think that is really a proposal for increasing the numbers. I think that is an argument for improving the quality. That, of course, has been an element of this debate-that by increasing the numbers somehow or other we will improve the quality. We have had this plaintive cry from the heart from members of Caucus, from Senator Robert Ray who just had a little chat to me across the room and from Senator Cook from Western Australia . Senator Robert Ray very passionately told us that if there were more members of parliament there would be a higher proportion of back benchers and that in the party room the Executive would not be so dominant. Senator Ray was a little bit naughty because he should have said that he was talking about Caucus for a start, because in Caucus people vote. He was doubly naughty when he alleged that the Executive members vote together, because in the Labor Party Caucus, members of the Executive, I gather, do not all vote together. Members of the Ministry can vote in ways other than Cabinet has indicated. I do not want to get into that argument. I just want to say that is a lot of rubbish.

SPEECH.PARA: The quality of an argument in my experience has far more often prevailed in the party room than have Executive numbers. Fortunately, on a majority of occasions, quality of argument and Executive numbers tend to coincide. But that is no argument at all because Senator Ray, if he were really telling us the whole truth about what goes on behind those closed doors in party rooms, would know that there is as big a risk of getting more sycophants into the party room who will not get up and say what they think because they are hoping for the next Cabinet appointment. I do not really think there is any consistency in the argument that more back benchers will improve the quality. What it is as likely to do is reduce the quality, because if we have the quality that we have, given the limited number of places in parliament, and Senator Ray thinks it could be higher--

TALK.START.PARA: —You just do not want to get knocked out of the shadow Ministry after having made it.

—I do not think there is anything wrong with being on the back bench. Senator Ray will come to enjoy it too. If this is the best we can do with the limited number we have, I would say that there is as logical an argument that by increasing the numbers all we will get is more people down the scale. If these are all the excellent brains that have managed to float through the political process to the top, that is as good as we will ever do. But I do not want to put down my colleagues in that way. I happen to think that the average standard in Parliament is really quite good. It is just a pity that more individuals do not get the opportunity to show more adequately to the public their full talents. I think that as we work here in the Senate and on committees we get a far better appreciation of individual talents. That argument really is a bit of a red herring.

SPEECH.PARA: The argument that I really found intriguing-again Senator Maguire put it in his speech; it has also appeared in print in just about every document or newspaper story I have seen on the subject-was that because there are so many more issues these days in which the national Parliament is involved, we need more colleagues to help us. I have been in the Senate for nine years and in that time there have been more issues than there were nine years before that. I do not find that there is anyone suggesting to me that somehow or other we ought just to confine ourselves to certain issues. I certainly do not find constituents suggesting to me that I should not spend time on this issue, or that I should just spend time on that issue and that it is okay not to be able to answer either for government or opposition on the range of issues that are available. However many members of parliament there are, all will have to vote in this Parliament on every issue that comes to a vote. We are not excused from a division because that issue is not our specialty. Every member of parliament will play a role in as many issues as possible. The additional issues argument is nonsense.

As has been said several times, what we need are some basic facilities to make us more effective. The problem with additional issues and the growth in the scope of parliament is that, as those issues have grown, as the Budget has grown , as the responsibilities of the national Government have grown, the means of helping us effectively to cope with that growth has not kept pace. Before I came into parliament nine years ago I worked in a university administration. I was au fait with what happened in administration and in offices. I would think that if I went back into the same office today I would not be able to operate half the equipment in it because I have not seen the modern equipment that is available. It certainly is not available to members of parliament.

I was mildly entertained, I must say, by one misinformed editorial in a newspaper which said that we did not need more members of parliament because we all had word processor machines. That was news to me because just a little while ago I wrote to the then Special Minister of State, Mr Mick Young, and raised the issue of word processor machines for members of parliament. We have more constituents than in the past, certainly members of the House of Representatives , who like to write to new constituents on the electoral role. That is an excellent idea because it is reaching out and communicating with people, telling them who their member of parliament is and how to contact the member's office. Members of the House of Representatives certainly need those facilities, but I feel a need for them in my work, too. In the reply received dated 5 July 1983, Mr Young said:
Cost is the major factor which militates against the provision of specialised equipment. There are 182 electorate offices and funds are not presently available to provide word processors to all.

In July this year the Government did not have the money to give its present members of parliament word processors but now, in November, it has the money to have all these additional members of parliament. We do need more staff, although I accept Senator Maguire's statement about the risks if members get too many staff. I am very well aware, from my contacts with members of the United States Congress, that when members get very large staffs unfortunately a lot of time is spent managing them, which gives members less time to have access to people.

The simple fact is that, during the time we spend in Canberra our offices have to keep functioning. Our constituents still have problems; they still need advice. They still want to bring problems concerning immigration, pensions or whatever to the office on a particular day and they cannot wait until Saturday morning or some other time when I have finished here-when I would not be able to do anything about it anyway. So the constituents contact my office and my staff handle all those routine queries. The honest truth is that the staffs of members of parliament do a very large amount of that sort of work. If members of parliament sit in their offices to answer routine queries, queries which come to them because people usually do not know where to go so they head for their member of parliament first to seek advice and assistance, they are wasting their electors' money. If they did not do that they would have the time to spend on all these issues for which they complain they need more time.

I am not advocating larger staffs for members, I am not here putting a case for a specific increase, but we do need some increase, of perhaps one or two people, as well as updated facilities. It would by much cheaper to provide that staff and those facilities to all of us as we are now than to have more politicians. Eventually, in any event, it will come. There will be more staff; there will be more facilities. Last year my office got a second electric typewriter for my second staff person, whom I have had since 1975. So these things do catch up with us eventually. I did not have one electric typewriter when I was elected in 1974. That is the pace of things and that is very sad because of the pressure it puts on our staff and because of the way in which it makes us less effective in serving our constituents than we would want to be.

I find 1949 numbers in this context a very poor joke. We keep on hearing how many members and votes there were before 1949 and there were many after 1949, and we are told that because an increase in members was seen as being necessary then as a result of the greater number of voters, an increase is necessary now. Remember that 1949 was before jet aircraft, electric typewriters-one thing that we have caught up with-and a whole lot of other things. For instance, now people have telephones in their homes and are able, even if they are bedridden, to make telephone calls to parliamentarians' offices.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petrol was rationed, too.
—People did not own cars. Very few people owned cars in 1949.
—I just made the point that petrol was rationed.

—Senator Colston makes the point that under the Labor Government petrol was still rationed four years after the war. It was indeed. A whole range of things have made us more effective, and so the raw figures are no longer an argument.
—We still open our own mail.

—Yes, we still open our own mail except when we bring one of our two staff here to do it. Senator Missen there makes the point that I was going to come to. It is one that Senator Robert Ray also raised. Senator Robert Ray, in about eighth grade debating style, took up the matter of cost of additional members of Parliament. He said that more members of Parliament may actually save us money. The strain of his argument, as I understood it, was that we have needed royal commissions to investigate certain things; royal commissions are very expensive but if we had more members of parliament we would not need so many royal commissions. That is a manpower question--
—It is a bit simplistic, but nevertheless--

—That was his argument, put simply. He did mention that royal commissions are more expensive than members of parliament. Senator Robert Ray said that if there had been more members of parliament, medifraud might have been exposed a little earlier and therefore that money would have--
—No, that is not--
—You did, Senator.
—I said it was a cheap investigation.
—Order! Senator Martin, could I suggest that you direct your remarks through the Chair and that might save some further interjections.
—I am trying very hard, Madam Acting Deputy President, but I keep on having my eyes diverted by Senator Ray's attention and it is rather difficult for me to concentrate.
—You are not the first one.

—It is difficult to miss him. Senator Robert Ray, from Victoria, was pursuing an argument and he did use the words, 'It may actually save money' in the context of medifraud and royal commissions. I suggest that we would be able to do our job better if we had the facilities, if the drudgery of our job was taken away. I have nothing against drudgery but, as Senator Missen has pointed out, the amount of time we spend just physically opening our mail or running down to the stationery room to get pencils because we have run out of them, or something like that, makes us the most overpaid messenger people in the world. If we had some staff to do that sort of thing and the time to spend on these important issues that Senator Robert Ray referred to, then we would be working more effectively, which is precisely what we are all talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: The question is: Will the money spent on these additional members of parliament be cost effective? Are we just going to get more people in the same position of not being able to do their jobs as well as they would like? Will we continue to be frustrated because we cannot do our job as well as we would like to? Will it be value for money? I am not utterly opposed for all time to increases in the numbers of parliament. I can see some merit in what Senator Missen was saying and I can see some merit in some enlargement. But that is not what this exercise is about.

If in 1949, for example, populations of electorates was the issue the number of representatives in the Senate would have been increased to more than 12 per State. If there was going to be any consistency in that argument we would now have more than 12 senators per State and we would have had an increase more than the proposed increase in the number of members of parliament that is being talked about now. But people have done their sums. For members of parliament not to be able to understand all the implications of a particular numerical increase is a bit like an English teacher who cannot read or write. It is basic to our job. I notice you smile, Madam Acting Deputy President. I realise that that might not have been the best analogy I could use. But most people would understand what I meant by that.

The simple fact is that this is about what is to the best advantage of the Government. It has not attempted to produce any consistency in its argument. It has not at any stage attempted to produce a straight line in its argument on cost effectiveness and value on the will of the people, on the number of voters since 1949. None of those things have hung together in a coherent line at any stage. 'Make Parliament more effective', they say, 'but do not make individual members of parliament effective.' As Mr Young said in July: 'We cannot afford a word processor for you, Senator. There is not enough money for that'. But there is money for more Labor senators, more Liberal senators and more National Party senators and members of the House of Representatives. It is not an issue of money at all for the Government. It is an issue of numbers and who wins elections and, regardless of who wins elections, who controls the Senate.

Senator Missen was charitable towards the end of his speech. He said that the Government by not thinking through this proposal will get a result that is bad for the Senate. Senator Missen is too charitable. Senator Missen, I think, was trying to cushion the blow for the Labor Party in what he was saying. The Government has thought through the proposal very well. It will get a result that is bad for the Senate and that is a result that is good for the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: — We are debating the Representation Bill 1983. This legislation, when passed, will have the effect of increasing the number of senators and consequently, as a result of constitutional requirements, the number of members in the House of Representatives. I think it is necessary when considering this legislation to set the stage by putting forward a few facts. The number of members of the Senate and the House of Representatives was last increased in 1948 and 1949. Since that time, among other things, the population has increased, or doubled, from 7.5 million to something over 15 million. The average enrolments in each electorate have increased from 39,948 to 74,989. Nobody would deny that Commonwealth Government activity has increased dramatically. In addition, more legislation is being passed and more committee work is being carried out. The story is endless.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess that if we do not accept the need for an increase now in the membership of the Parliament we are in effect saying that those who have gone before us have not had much work to do. I think that would be a reflection on all those who have served this country well in both this chamber and the House of Representatives. We have all known people who have served in both chambers and none of us would say that they were bludgers on the community or on the taxpayer . Nonetheless, we must acknowledge that the work load has increased over that period. More people have to be represented; more legislation has to be passed; more committee work has to be undertaken; and so it goes on. Senator Robert Ray has already alluded to the fact that the membership of the Press gallery has increased fourfold. Since 1949, the Press Gallery has increased fourfold to report an increased volume of news from the same number of senators and members.

In the intervening period, Australia, for better or for worse, has come nearer to the welfare state. Honourable senators can relate many stories of people who have come to their offices in connection with benefits that they have or to which they are entitled. They have spoken to us about things that have gone wrong, about cheques that have been lost in the mail and decisions that have been taken against them. The story is endless. In addition, the electorate now has a far greater expectation about what it should receive by way of representation from its elected representatives. We are often told that we have more politicians per head of population than any other country. If we want to make that sort of comparison we need to take into consideration the work load that is expected of politicians in this country. In many countries responsibility for schools and housing is taken at the local council or county council level. Therefore, it is pretty hard to draw an analogy between what happens in other countries and what happens in Australia. I understand that there are more electors in the electorates of members of the House of Representatives than there are in most electorates in the United Kingdom, Canada and New Zealand, to name three countries that come to mind. Also, the work load on our elected representatives in Australia is not less than just about any country that one can look at, and is probably far greater.

Of course, mention has been made of the public opinion polls that have been taken. If any person or any party does not take notice of public opinion in either the long term or the short term they will be in trouble. Opinion polls have shown that the people think that we do not need more parliamentarians. I would like to see the result of a poll which asked whether politicians should be paid or whether they should have an increase in pay and whether the taxpayers should pay tax or should have to pay increased tax. We all know what the results of such polls would be. There are times in this Parliament when we have to take decisions which might be contrary to public opinion. I pose this question: Do the people who answer these opinion polls really know what the life of a politician is all about? I think that very few of them know what it is like. I have found as I have moved around that the few people who do understand our situation have a great deal of sympathy for members of all political parties and the life- style they lead. Can any honourable senators say that we lead a normal lifestyle? Can any honourable senators say that we spend time with our families as people in ordinary jobs do? Whichever criteria we look at we have a different lifestyle and a different work load from other people in the community. I think we all acknowledge that our families suffer considerably when we come into this chamber or into the other place to serve as elected representatives.

If we oppose this legislation, are we saying that the numbers currently in the House of Representatives and the Senate should be entrenched and that there should never be an increase? If we are not saying that, why cannot we accept an increase now when all parties in this Parliament agreed in 1966 that there should be an increase in the number of members? I take it a little further down the track: That proposal did not go ahead because the nexus could not be broken. At that stage agreement had been reached that the number of members in both Houses could and should be increased if the nexus could be broken. Has the work load decreased? Were those people who took that decision in 1966-some of them are still here now; many are known to us-saying that they were not working to their full extent and that we are just reaching our peak? Of course not.

The work load and all that is expected of an elected representative in this country has increased. Of course, with shifts and increases in population, changes have been made to electoral boundaries. Some electorates have become much larger and, consequently, are far harder to serve. I will mention some of the electorates in my own State without examining those in other States. The electorate of Kennedy comprises 663,153 square kilometres which is nine times the size of Tasmania or twice the size of Victoria. The electorate of Leichhardt , in the far north, comprises 406,650 square kilometres which is five times the size of Tasmania and almost twice the size of Victoria. The electorate of Maranoa comprises 517,400 square kilometres which is seven times the size of Tasmania or more than twice the size of Victoria. There have been changes in the work load of members of parliament and in the expectations of the electorate. Many electorates have had increases in population. The size of others has increased dramatically.

What is representation all about? Unfortunately, in some people's minds, representation means that they go into the polling booth on election day and cast their votes and that is all there is to it. I suggest that representation means far more than that. As well as being able to cast a vote representation means the right to be properly and fully served by one's member of parliament and to be able to converse and consult with him. He must be able to offer and be receptive to ideas and see at first hand community and industry problems. In short, representation is the principle of the visibility of the legislator.
