In recent times, as the work load of members of Parliament has increased and electorates have got larger, it has become harder for people to be properly and adequately represented. In other words, the principle of the visibility of the legislator is getting harder to uphold. A person who does not have access to a telephone is discriminated against. Other people cannot hear regular news broadcasts or read newspapers regularly. Others may have inadequate transport. The votes of those people are being devalued while that situation exists and when other people have all those things available to them. They cannot converse and consult with their elected representatives as well as the majority of people can. While electorates are getting larger people's votes are being devalued all the time.

I notice that a notice of motion has been given about the economic impact of this legislation. I suggest that once we have a parliament we are committed to expenditure. If we do not like that line let us forget about a parliament and put in a benevolent or other kind of dictator. Look at all the money we would save! Once we are committed to a parliament we are committed to expending X amount of dollars. If we want parliament to work properly and people to be adequately and fully represented, all of them, not just those who live within two blocks of their elected representatives' offices, we are committed to spending X amount of dollars, come what may. I believe people in this country accept the fact that we should have an elected parliament and that they should be able to consult and converse with their elected representatives. Those representatives should be fully knowledgeable about their areas and the industries in them. On that basis we are obviously committed to spending X amount of dollars. When people realise that that is the situation obviously they will accept it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have a view about the particular effects upon the Senate as opposed to the lower House?
—I will come to that very shortly. Yes, I have. It is unfortunate that the nexus was not broken in 1966.
—That is where the problem is.
—That is correct. I hope that the people who are listening to this debate--
—You are a Queenslander. You should be the last one to want the nexus broken. You ask Senator Bjelke-Petersen.

—Senator Watson should keep his cool. He will have his chance. Senator Walters spoke on behalf of Tasmania and said that the Senate would be swamped if we broke the nexus. She has a complete misunderstanding of the powers of the Senate as defined in the Constitution. The Senate stands on the powers of the Constitution. It will not be swamped by the House of Representatives or anything else. If we cannot stand on our own against no matter how many people are put in the House of Representatives, we might as well pack up and go home. The powers of the Senate are in the Constitution. I believe the people of Australia look to the Senate and to its committee system more than they do to the House of Representatives, such is the standing of the Senate and its committee system in the community today. The Tasmanians are worried about being swamped. How Tasmania, as an original State, can worry about being swamped by the House of Representatives when, because of its population, it can muster only five members of the House of Representatives, yet it has 10 senators and, ultimately, 12, beats me. I say to Senator Watson that 'populate or perish' is still in good standing. I return to the point that I believe ultimately the nexus should and will be broken. I hope that the people of Australia who happen to be listening to the debate today will accept the fact that at some future time that question must be put to the people. It is something to which they must address their minds very shortly if this Parliament is to function and if they are to be adequately represented. That said, we are in the situation that the nexus has not been broken and we must go down the track of increasing the size of both Houses in line with the Constitution-in the case of the Senate to 12 representatives per State. I believe that the work load needed to justify such action does exist. The committee system alone demands that we have more senators . The question of manning not only the standing committees but also any select committees that might come up has already arisen. Since the nexus has not been broken, we can certainly adequately use the services of additional senators.

SPEECH.PARA: Mention has been made of the fact that we could end up with a hung Senate because an even number of senators will come from each State following every half-Senate election. As I see it, we could have a hung Senate as the Senate is constituted now. All that is needed is for three States to vote, as to six senators, for the Government and, as to four senators for the Opposition, and the other three States to vote, as to four senators, for the Government and, as to six senators, for the Opposition, with an equal number of territorial representatives voting for each side. That would produce a hung Senate. I repeat , it could happen now, so let us forget all this rot about there being more likelihood of having a hung Senate if six senators from each State are elected at every half-Senate election and 12 in the case of a double dissolution.

I pay tribute to the statistics section of the Parliamentary Library for its response to the burden that has been placed on it in the last couple of weeks since these Bills have been brought down. It has done a fantastic job in such a short time. None of the projections that it has made-having looked at Senate elections from 1949 to 1983 in relation to there being 12 senators from each State, or six following a half-Senate election-show that we would have hung Senates, any more than we would have now. Indeed, if we look at the double dissolution figures, which are basically the same-we have even numbers, either 10 or six being elected from each State-we find that in no case have these resulted in a hung Senate. In 1951, when there were six senators from each State -the situation that we are discussing now-the results were: Australian Labor Party 28, Liberal Party 26, National Party six-or 32 for the Liberal-National Party coalition, or Liberal-Country Party coalition, as it was then known, as against 28 for the Labor Party. How does the hung Senate theory stand in the face of those figures?

TALK.START.PARA: —Sorry, the figure must have been 10 per State; they add up to 60.

—I stand corrected. There was an even number of 10 for each State. Never, when there have been 10 senators from each State, also representatives of the Territories, as I see the figures, has a majority been held by the Labor Party. For 1951 its representation was 28, for 1974 it was 29, for 1975 it was 27 and for 1983 it is 30. Here we had double dissolutions as a result of which even numbers of senators in each State were elected by the people, yet a hung Senate did not result. Thus, actual figures as well as projections arrived at by the Library confirm what I have said. The National Party supports the Bill for these reasons. Our Party, above all others, has always been concerned that everyone should have adequate representation. We are probably as conscious as any, and more conscious than most, of the inadequate representation because of the large rural electorates, the inadequate transport, telephone and mail services and all the rest. We are as conscious as anybody, and maybe more conscious than others, of the work load that is involved. I have put forward the position of the National Party and given reasons for why we support this Bill. I thank the chamber for its indulgence. Our position is now on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there is a strong element of cynicism both in this debate and in the Bill we are debating, the Representation Bill 1983. There has been a great deal of talk about high principles but in reality various political parties are attempting to preserve what they have and, if possible, grab a little more by manipulating the political system to that end. I would like to tell those who look at the matter this way a cautionary tale. The same coalition increased the number of members of the Victorian State Parliament from 81 to 88. But I think that the Australian Labor Party is now very distressed at the results of the boundary redistribution. The result has not achieved the very obvious political objectives it had. So although one can be cynical in what one is trying to do, cynicism does not always triumph, which is a very good moral principle, I suppose.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, there are a number of arguments for an increase in the size of the House of Representatives and somewhat different arguments for an increase in the size of the Senate. As others on this side of the House and I are opposed to this Bill, we have to look at those arguments and explain why we do not accept them. The first argument is that there has been a substantial increase in population since the Parliament was fixed in size in 1949. Since 1949 there has been a 95 per cent increase in population, or, looking at it another way, there has been a 91.5 per cent increase in the number of voters. The reason that the increase in voters is less than the increase in general population is partly demographic and partly because many more people in the community are not naturalised and are therefore not entitled to vote than was the case in 1949. By any standards, an almost doubling of the population is a significant increase and one which, on its face, seems to justify an increase in the number of members of parliament.

The second argument that has been advanced is that there has been a vast increase in the amount of electoral work. The number of people who make approaches to their members of parliament has increased. I think that is undeniable. Even in my time in parliament I have seen a steady increase in the amount of electoral work. The question arises, though, whether the best way to deal with this is to increase the number of members of parliament or to increase the number of members of their staff so that parliamentarians can do their duties more effectively. Nevertheless, it is a fact that we have a great deal of work to do-much more than in most other parliaments.

The other day I was reading the autobiography of the young life of a prominent former British Conservative Minister, Mr Julian Amery. He recalled when he was first preselected for the electorate of Preston in the north west of England. He visited the electorate for the first time to receive the formal acceptance. He was about 22 at the time. He spoke to the electorate chairman-he had not previously visited the town of Preston-and said to him: 'Would you expect me to live here?' The electorate committee chairman said: 'Good God, no! You are a young man. You want to sow some wild oats. You must sow those in London. Do not do anything like that up here'. Mr Amery asked: 'Well, how often do you expect me to visit the electorate?' The chairman answered: 'Once a month. If you come more often it will cease to be news. If you come less often they will think that you are neglecting them. Once a month would be just right.' I would hate to see any member of this Parliament endeavour to get away with that. People have a far greater expectation of what they are entitled to from their members of parliament in Australia. That expectation is undoubtedly increasing. Nevertheless, I make the point whether the right way of handling this problem is to increase the staff available to the members rather than increase the number of members.

Another argument that has been advanced is that there has been a growth in the number of Ministers since 1949. Obviously this decreases the number of back benchers in the Government party, and the same thing happens with shadow Ministers and back benchers in the Opposition. Therefore, there is an imbalance between the Ministry and the back bench. I think this is true, but I do not know that we would solve it by the method proposed. I think the 26 or 27-person Ministry is absurd. Looked at on any rational, organisational principle, 20 departments would be plenty. The reasons why there are more than 20 departments are essentially political, but they are related also to the number of members of the party.

If we increase the number of members of parliament we will undoubtedly increase the size of the Ministry. The British House of Commons has about 600 members, with over 100 members in the Ministry. I do not think, by increasing the number of members of Parliament, we will improve the balance between back benchers and Ministers. All we will do is retain the same balance and increase the number of Ministers, I think to the degradation of our standard of administration and to the very great expense of the community. Every Minister has to have a department with a permanent secretary, a deputy secretary, a first assistant secretary, and so on. It is an enormously expensive thing to establish more ministries. In my view that would be the inevitable consequence of increasing the number of members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Should you not have more Executive members, even if you do not have more departments, to ease the pressure on Ministers?

—I think we should but we should do it in a different way. That is a rather different issue. Rather than increasing the number of Ministers, a more appropriate way would be to involve more of the party through the device of parliamentary secretaries, who do not have to be paid. That is a different issue . I am merely saying that I am quite sure the consequences of increaseing the number of members of parliament would be, for inevitable, perhaps irresistible, political reasons, to increase the number of Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look now at the argument for more senators. No one seems to have advanced much in this area. The main argument is a rather negative one, that is, that we are compelled to do so by the nexus. If we want to increase the number of members of the House of Representatives we have to increase the number of senators because the Constitution requires the number of members of the House of Representatives to be twice the number of senators. An attempt in 1967 to break this nexus failed in I think the most humiliating defeat of any single referendum proposal ever put. Although we have passed a Bill in this House to put the referendum to the people again on this subject, I doubt whether the Government will ever bring that on, nor, I am afraid, if it were put would it pass.

Senator Missen is the only person who has really argued for more senators. He argued that the Senate as it stands, with 64 members, is overworked and that our committee system is working less effectively than it should. I agree with him, but not for the reason he gave. In my view, the reason our committee system is not working as well as it should, although it has advanced greatly in the last two decades, is primarily because of the way in which we operate; our method of duplicating the role of the House of Representatives rather than looking at the complementary role and using our committees to fullest advantage as committees of review of what the Executive is doing and distancing this Senate from the Executive. That is a different method of operation of the Senate, but if we want our system to work effectively, as I do, I do not think the right answer is a totally unnecessary increase in the number of senators. Rather we should use existing senators more effectively and more creatively.

I should like briefly to look at some of the other arguments that have been advanced. I have touched briefly on the increase in electoral work. We have one more staff member now than members of parliament had in 1949. There is approval in principle of a recommendation that we should have a third staff member. The current argument used against that is not whether the extra staff member is needed-clearly there is need-but where the staff member would go. Most people want to have their extra staff member in Parliament House. Frankly, there is not room in this Parliament House for every member and senator to have an extra staff member. That is the crunch-the physical limitations of this Parliament House. When that problem is solved with the construction of the new Parliament House certainly members should have an additional staff member.

I mentioned earlier the increase in population since 1949, but is that a justification for more members of Parliament? There are two factors in deciding how many members of Parliament we need. The first factor is the geographical size of the country. We have a country which is slightly smaller that the United States of America; nevertheless it is a very large country. The second factor is the number of electors each member represents. Since 1949 the size of the country has not changed. If one looks at the problems of dealing with a large electorate one sees that many things have improved since 1949. We have much better roads, much better cars, aircraft and charter flights are available to members who have large electorates. As I mentioned earlier, our staff has been doubled-it will soon be trebled-since 1949. Telephones have been greatly improved since 1949 and matters that would have required a visit or a letter can now be dealt with promptly by telephone. That leg of the argument for increasing the number of members has no substance; changes such as I have mentioned have reduced the argument for an increase in the number of members of the House of Representatives.

With regard to the number of voters, or the population-it makes little difference which one we use as the criterion for an increase-we must accept that as the population increases the ratio of people to members of parliament must go down. In the draft Constitution of 1891 it was proposed that there should be one member of the House of Representatives for every 30,000 people. If that had been the Constitution we adopted and approved at the 1891 convention, there would now be 513 members of the House of Representatives. I think even the National Party of Australia would agree that that would be too big.

The United States House of Representatives now has 435 members and they have an average of 540,000 people to represent. Honourable senators should remember that the United States is a country very much the same size as ours, although the size does not come into it as it is just population we are talking about now. If we used the United States criteria for our House of Representatives we would have a House of Representatives consisting of 29 members. I think we would all agree that that would be too small. On the other hand if the United States used our present population criteria for its House of Representatives it would consist of 2,750 members as compared with their actual 435. Looking at those sorts of figures I do not think any case has been made as to why we need more members of parliament because the population has gone up. We certainly do not need more members because the country has got larger; it has not. Communication has become easier. The population has gone up but that is counterbalanced by improvements in communications. I can see no strong case for an increase in the number of members of parliament looking at international examples in other federations. But even if there were a case I cannot see any possible justification for making the change before 1988.

Where will these extra 36 members go in this Parliament? Where will they be accommodated? What arrangements have been made for them? That is a physical problem. If we were to accommodate them there would have to be very substantial structural alterations made to this building in the last few years of its life in its present role and that would be absurd. It would be an expensive and absurd thing to do. There is not only the physical problem with this Parliament House. What about the cost? How much is this change going to cost the community? I would like to read a brief extract from a statement made on 7 September this year by the Minister for Finance (Mr Dawkins). This is what he said:
In the future all--
I repeat the word 'all'--

second reading speeches of Ministers will include a statement of the financial impact of the legislation. These statements will include estimates of any significant costs, revenues and savings arising directly from that legislation where such estimates can be calculated readily and reliably. Where that information is not available, Ministers will include a brief explanation of the circumstances in their second reading speeches and outline in broad terms the expected financial impact of the legislation.

We have had no detailed or broad estimate of the cost of this legislation. Thirty-six additional members! How much are they to cost? What about the facilities for them-the staff, the offices, including the offices in Parliament House, their travel and their allowances? What is the cost of this proposal by the Government? Where is the promised financial impact statement? I believe that no real case has been made for the need for these additional members of parliament; no case has been made on grounds of practicality and costs. This increase, which may ultimately be justified when the case can be made, certainly should not be done at least until the new Parliament House is available in 1988.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate is debating the Representation Bill to increase the number of members of the House of Representatives and the Senate. This Bill to increase the size of parliament is but another demonstration of politicians' attitudes being out of step with those prevailing in the community. Looking closer at the tactics, they can be seen rather cynically, I believe, to improve marginally the electoral support of not only the Australian Labor Party but also the National Party of Australia in the House of Representatives to the detriment and to the cost of all taxpayers, since it is the taxpayers who have to meet these bills in the end. It is not only the direct costs; there is also a whole host of indirect costs which far exceed the direct costs of paying and employing a politician. Another view could be that this is a further demonstration of the Australian Labor Party's desire to promote its philosophy of centralisation to the detriment of the rights of the States and to the detriment of the Federation. What we should be doing is trying to confine the powers of this Federal Parliament and transfer powers back to the States where they belong. I think we are tending to move away from our Constitution and the intentions of our founding fathers on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: All the speeches we have heard this afternoon from the other side are just following the Parkinson theory: The more people you have, the more work there is to do, and so on. I think the tragedy-particularly from the Senate's point of view-is that increasing the number of senators from each of the States from 10 to 12 will mean that at each half Senate election with half the senators retiring there will be a greater opportunity for the major parties to secure three senators each, since only 43 per cent of the total vote for the major parties would bring about that situation. If there was an odd number to be returned at each half Senate election-three, five or seven-there is more likely to be a clear cut mandate, but at the same time it does provide an opportunity for minor parties to get some representation. I think one of the problems that we have to face realistically in the long run is that a continual deadlock of the Senate is more likely to reduce the power of the Senate in the long run. An even number of seats would tend to ensure that voters' preferences would be more adequately reflected. I think this is a very important point, particularly for the smaller parties. It is such an important point that the Australian Democrats have realised it and, I think, Senator Harradine has realised it. They realise that an odd number of senators being returned from each State is more likely to reflect voters' preferences. If the National Party will listen it will find that this is true. I find it quite strange that as a national party-a minor party-it has overlooked this fundamental principle because its return is very dependent on preferences.

From my own State's point of view, all Tasmanian senators and members of the House of Representatives-those members are Kevin Newman, Bruce Goodluck, Ray Groom, Michael Hodgman and Max Burr-are against an increase in the number of members of parliament. The Tasmanian Executive of the Liberal Party is very much against any increase in the number of members of parliament. Tasmania would be disadvantaged by an increase in numbers, particularly in the House of Representatives, where its numbers would not increase. These are the plain facts . Tasmania will continue to have only five members in the House of Representatives, the minimum provided by our Constitution. Therefore Tasmania's proportion of the total number in the House of Representatives will be smaller than it is now.

As members of the Senate, we believe we represent our States as much as we represent our own parties. Therefore, people from Tasmania are expected to vote against this sort of proposition. The proposal to increase the Senate by two representatives from each State is a ploy by the ALP to eliminate the minor parties and thereby strengthen its own position. I think it is quite incredible that our National Party colleagues in this chamber will not support the need to put a brake on increasing the number of members of parliament.

I think it must be extremely difficult for some senators, two of whom, my colleagues Senator Bjelke-Petersen and Senator Boswell, I know have been under extreme pressure. I know they have pangs of conscience about this matter, but the pressure from the local party machine has been so intense that they have to follow what was said in the House of Representatives and not what Queensland Premier Joh Bjelke-Petersen might think. Joh is right. I have a great deal of pity for these two colleagues who are under intense pressure. I only hope that there could be some delay in the passage of this Bill because with the passage of time reason will be seen to prevail in that quarter.

Some honourable senators spoke of the need for senators to have extra staff. Although such a move would make life very much more comfortable for members of parliament it would remove them further from their electorates. In fact, members of parliament need to be far closer to their electorates and not separated from them by a plethora of sheltering staff. In many cases extra staff-that is, the unscrupulous or less scrupulous ones-would be merely ensuring working towards the re-election of their member or senator rather than helping the electorate. In so doing they would be entrenching the position of the parliamentarian and making it very much more difficult for outsiders to challenge his position and to succeed.

I acknowledge that our work load is indeed heavy, but we must destroy the myth that this job in Canberra is an easy and lucrative one. It has been well recognised that Australia has a high ratio of politicians to electors. I submit that we do not need an increase in the size of this Parliament. Let us, in preference, reform some of our procedures and practices to ensure that, for example, the archaic voting system in the Senate is changed and brought up to date and that modern equipment is used to expedite debates. I believe this is a better approach than increasing the number of parliamentarians. Let us improve the productivity and effectiveness of parliamentarians. For heaven's sake, let us not increase the number of members of parliament. The people do not want an increase and it is not necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: -I rise to speak briefly in this debate. The National Party of Australia and I propose to support the Government on this issue. I do not want it to be assumed that I have suddenly become beholden to the socialist political philosophy.
—Shame!

—I am sure Senator Primmer understands that very well. The issue that the Government has introduced through this proposed legislation echoes an attitude that has been held by the leadership and the organisation of my Party for a considerable number of years. In fact, it was first promoted something like 17 years ago when, regrettably, an attempt to break the nexus failed. I believe that there would be no emotion to speak of in a debate such as this if there were an opportunity to break the nexus on this occasion and merely increase in some measure the numbers in the House of Representatives. There is an excellent argument to establish that as being a proper and responsible policy . However, I understand that the Government is not inclined, at least at this time, to consider enabling a decision to be made on the breaking of the nexus.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the question of increasing the numbers in the Commonwealth Parliament is in the final resort a matter of judgment. There can be no doubt that statistics and a whole range of other arguments-they have been flying to and fro across this chamber for several hours already-indicate the logic, indeed the necessity, for true representation in this Parliament to be achieved by a modest increase in the size of the House of Representatives so that the constant enlargement of electorates in this massive country ceases and there can be a real closing of the gap in personal contact between the elected representative and those who put him in the parliament to develop, promote and implement the sort of legislation that they believe to be proper.

Effective representation, surely, is the very essence of the democracy that we all support. Without effective representation we will slowly become the victims of executives and bureaucracies. We cannot allow that sort of thing to happen. Effective representation is not identified purely by a statistic. Effective representation surely relates to the real communication, the personal communication, between the representative and those people whom he represents. That is what I believe to be effective representation. It is the quality of representation that is important. It is not something that can be simplified into a mere statistic or ratio.

There is also a need to recall the obvious. In any case, a Federal redistribution is due. There will be a redistribution. We have to be aware that ultimately, be it this year, next year or in five or 10 years, an increase in the number of representatives in this Parliament is inevitable. I believe everyone is of that view. If indeed it is inevitable, when is the right time? Clearly, it is never the right time. That has been said several times. It is common to read in the paragraphs of the news media and it is common to hear in the street, in the club or in the pub that it is always the wrong time to increase, of all things, the number of members of parliament in this country.

So we have to start somewhat behind scratch, because it would appear that it is never the right time. However, the Government proposes in this legislation that the right time is now. Having looked at both sides of the argument, I believe that this is probably as good a time as any. If this chance goes by and redistribution takes place next year, it may well be ten years before the next responsible redistribution occurs and before the Parliament can once again look at how many members should be in this institution.

As I have said, we will wait for perhaps ten years for that sort of investigation and determination to happen again. In ten years time, I suggest that the average number of electors in an electorate may be in the vicinity of 100,000. Already, it is almost double what it was 34 years ago. In another ten years it may well be edging towards the 100,000 mark. I believe that most reasonable people would agree that it is rather ridiculous to assume that one member of parliament is capable of properly representing that number of people.

It seems to me that on balance a moderate increase in members is justified now, and if it occurs now there is every probability that it will see us through to the early decades of the twenty-first century. If implementation of this proposal is delayed for another ten years or whatever, it would bring us to a point about five years after the opening of the new Parliament House. The new Parliament House would be found to be already incapable of handling the work load which was proposed, a mere five years after its first occupation.

I have already mentioned in my opening remarks that it is a great pity, in my view, that we could not have seen fit to enable the nexus to be broken. This would have meant that we could have increased the membership of the legislature without at this time altering the numbers in the Senate. There is a strong case, as I said, for a modest increase in the number of members in the House of Representatives. I will mention a few of the reasons for it in a moment or two. There is also a case for an increase in the number of senators in this chamber, because, as many people have indicated in the context of this debate, the responsibilities and the avenues of operation of members of the Senate have increased enormously both in width and in depth in the last 10 to 15 years in particular. The time of the Senate is taken up very significantly with the work of the committee system. The committee system has been making, is making and, I believe, will make a direct and positive contribution to the working of this Parliament. It is indeed probably one of the best braking forces that the electorate has on any government of any political persuasion and the fact that in depth investigation of various matters-legislative matters in the main-but a lot of other matters too, can and does occur is of very great significance.

However, in the few minutes that remain for me to speak this afternoon, I draw attention to the circumstances that have existed in the Senate over a number of years. The concept of a Senate where the government does not have an absolute majority has been the circumstance for most of the last 30 years. Indeed, I think that except for the latter half of the 1970s no government of either persuasion has actually commanded an absolute majority in the Senate. As a purely political entity, I would far prefer that a government of which I happen to be a member had control of the Senate. It would be a simpler operation. I am sure that the Australian Labor Party would obviously sooner control the Senate. However, it is worth considering whether that is as enormously important as we, on the surface, think it is. I say that for a couple of reasons. There is the widespread allegation in the community that the Senate is not really worth a bumper because it is only a mirror of the House of Representatives anyway. There seems to me to be one way of ensuring that it is always only a mirror image and that is to make it exactly the same composition, majority-wise if not in actual numbers, of the House of Representatives. That would tend to make it something of a mirror image. It would tend to lend credence to the assertion that it is a rubber stamp.

That takes me to the second reason. I believe that we underestimate, certainly in this Parliament and, I believe, in the electorate, the power of the Senate and the responsibility that that power imposes. I do not believe that this Senate, controlled by any particular group of people, an opposition or a small party can act irresponsibly. It cannot afford to act in a frivolous manner. Consequently, that power, that measure of responsibility, is a very real restraint on frivolous and irresponsible behaviour because ultimately, if whichever party controls this chamber uses its power and its control in a frivolous and irresponsible manner, its masters who are the electors of this country will very quickly, dramatically and emphatically exhibit to the party that it has done totally the wrong thing and has misused the power and the responsibility it has been given. I do not think we should forget that.

I have heard a couple of arguments that are matters of interest. I have a great deal of concern for what was said. The view was expressed by, I think, Senator Jessop earlier today that the real answer lay in a greater number of staff being provided. I believe that a greater number of staff could certainly be used very profitably. But I think, from the point of view of the electorate at large, it needs to have closer contact with its own representatives. The electorate is not really interested in having X plus Y numbers of public servants to talk to. It likes to talk to the Senator Evanses or Senator Lewises and the various members of this Parliament. That is what the electorate is chiefly concerned with. I do not think an increase in staff would really get around the problem of having a few more members to represent the people of this country.

It was my determination to exhibit some of the extraordinary difficulties of the vast electorates of Australia. I do not really have time to go into that matter in depth on this occasion. There are circumstances whereby in my own State of New South Wales two extra metropolitan seats have been lost in the last few years. There is the case of the electorate of Gwydir, which is now three times the physical size that it was 15 years ago. There are many electorates in which members of parliament, in travel lines from A to B, travel a distance greater than from London to Edinburgh. I know that my time has run out. I want to make the point that we do believe this is a serious and worthwhile contribution to representation in this country, and I would urge its support.

Wine Statutory Authority to Continue
The Minister for Primary Industry, Mr John Kerin, today announced his intention to continue with a statutory authority for the wine industry.

The Minister said there were a range of issues which could only be tackled successfully on a collective industry basis. These included research, consumer information, forecasting grape supply and demand, and preservation and enhancement of the industry's image in domestic and export markets. There was a particular problem to be tackled in trying to get grape plantings by variety into better balance with demand, Mr Kerin said.

An authority such as the Australian Wine and Brandy Corporation (AWBC), funded by industry, was needed to ensure these issues were adequately addressed. A properly co-ordinated approach served both winemaker and grapegrower interests.

Recent controversy within industry about the role and functions of the AWBC had received a good deal of publicity. Some large wine companies had suggested that the Corporation was unnecessary, but many other winemakers and independent winegrape growers saw a continuing need for a statutory authority funded by a statutory levy on industry.
Mr Kerin said it appeared that the differences of opinion were more concerned with the means of achieving objectives rather than about the objectives themselves.
He said he was prepared to consider amending the AWBC legislation to ensure that the industry's statutory authority was cost effective and was structured and funded in an equitable way.

The Minister proposes to call an early meeting with a broadly representative group to discuss the changes which may need to be made. He said he attaches prime importance to this meeting in helping the Government to find solutions to the industry's problems.
Mr Kerin will also be seeking industry views on means of achieving adjustment in the industry to overcome grape surpluses and other problems.
Mr Kerin said diversity and strong individualism were essential characteristics of the image and mystique of wine.

'Those characteristics need to be retained but not to an extent which precludes a collective approach to industry-wide issues and problems. The industry needs to pull together in tackling those issues', he added.

Father Joseph Chen, who is aged 75, was sentenced in March 1983 for 11 years for 'colluding with foreigners'. Father Stephen Chen, who is aged 66, is in gaol as well. Father Stanislaus Shen, who is aged 80 years and was sentenced for 10 years, is now believed to be in hospital. He was charged with 'hampering production and modernisation'. The charge of hampering production was laid against him because he organised a pilgrimage to a celebrated shrine of the Virgin Mary. About 3,000 people took part, most of them fishermen; hence he was charged with hampering production. He suffers from a heart condition.

There are two others to whom I wish to refer-Father Francis Zhu and Fu Shengi. The latter was born in 1954 in a workers' family in Shanghai. He was a member of the Communist Youth League. In 1979 he helped to found Voice of Democracy. The magazine expressed support of the Polish Solidarity paper and was declared 'anti -Party and anti-socialist'. He was Editor of Responsibility. In 1980 he stood as a candidate in the election of local People's Representatives in a southern district in Shanghai. According to Amnesty International, elections were rigged. The factory officials threatened that those who voted for Fu would not receive a wage rise. I am aware of the time, but I believe that it would be opportune to raise these matters with our visitors from Shanghai, although they may not even know about the people I have mentioned. I seek leave to table Amnesty International documents relating to a number of these prisoners.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. This morning I did not have the opportunity of asking a particular question which I would like to have registered. The question is addressed to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). Has the Attorney-General been contacted by the Police Association of the Northern Territory about actions of solicitors employed by the Central Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service in advising demonstrators who have been arrested at Pine Gap? Is the Attorney-General aware whether solicitors, other than Pam Ditton, employed by CAALAS have been involved? If so, can he confirm that they are on leave and that funds appropriated to assist Aborigines are not being used to assist non-Aboriginal protesters? Is the Attorney-General in a position to confirm or otherwise, firstly, that CAALAS vehicles were utilised to attend the demonstration and, secondly, a CAALAS vehicle was not available to take an Aboriginal youth to court yesterday?

SPEECH.PARA: There are many things I would like to say about the matter but I will say them at some future time. The question I have asked today was prompted by a telegram I received yesterday, 17 November, from Mr Carter, President of the Northern Territory Police Association and Mr Plumb, President of the Northern Territory Commissioned Officers Police Association. The telegram that I received commences : 'The following telegram has this day been forwarded to the Attorney-General'. It reads:

Thank you for your response to our telegram regarding the incidents at Pine Gap stop To ensure that you are under no misunderstanding we point out that of the 129 women arrested at Pine Gap 128 were arrested by the Australian Federal Police stop The roll of Northern Territory Police was merely one of crowd management and containment at the base and later processing and detention of Federal Police prisoners at the Alice Springs watchhouse stop It is still our assertion that there has been a misuse of funds by Central Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service in that a number of solicitors from that service have been directly and indirectly involved in defending and advising arrested demonstrators stop The duty solicitor mentioned in your reply to Senator Crowley has been constantly accompanied by Mrs Pam Ditton of CAALAS stop Mrs Pam Ditton is one of the organisers and co-ordinators of the demonstration and has been on paid and unpaid leave since 10th November 1983 stop It is our information that yesterday (16 November) the CAALAS did not have a vehicle available to convey an Aboriginal youth to court at Alice Springs because their vehicles were being utilized to attend to the demonstrators stop

As I said, the telegram was signed by the presidents of both the Northern Territory Police Association and the Northern Territory Commissioned Officers Police Association. At a later date I will have more to say regarding the matter but I ask the Government to look into it and advise the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in the chamber when Senator Harradine spoke and I will briefly reply to him. First of all, I will refer the matters he raised to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden). Briefly, the Government and the Department are conscious of Amnesty International's concern about civil rights in China, particularly as the last annual report of Amnesty International referred to the imprisonment of people such as Father Zhu and the archbishop who has been imprisoned in Shanghai. It also referred to the detention of prisoners generally, the anti-crimes campaign, as it is called in China, and the widespread use of the death penalty in that country. The Department has been monitoring the situation and the Government has been kept fully informed.

SPEECH.PARA: The case of Father Vincent Zhu is one that I remember coming up. It was brought up particularly by Amnesty, which I think wrote a letter about it. The Australian Embassy in Peking has already been asked to seek specific information on this case and to raise it on suitable occasions with the authorities in China . I would have thought that it was appropriate to raise such a matter with the visiting group. I will certainly inform the Minister for Foreign Affairs of Senator Harradine's views.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the matter raised by Senator Kilgariff, I indicate that I have received the telegram , which he very kindly read into the record, from the Northern Territory Police Association and the Northern Territory Commissioned Officers Police Association. I note the points that are made therein and I will refer the use of Central Aboriginal Australian Legal Aid Service resources to my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding), whose responsibility the matter comes under . I make the point, however, that it seems to me that the complaints that are made about the role played by Mrs Pam Ditton in this matter are utterly ill conceived to the extent that it seems to be acknowledged in the telegram that Mrs Ditton has been on leave during these events. If the suggestion is made that it is somehow inappropriate for an employee of a legal service in her own time to engage in activities involving the exercise of free speech and the right to protest, that is not a perspective that I share or, I would hope that any Australians with a fair minded respect of civil liberties would share. To the extent that that is an apparent ground for criticism, I reject it wholly. To the extent that the allegation is that Central Australian Aboriginal Legal Aid Service resources are being employed in ways that are inappropriate for such resources to be employed there may be two views on the matter and I will ensure that a reply is received by the honourable senator in that respect.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate stands adjourned until Tuesday, 29 November at 2 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 October 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is a Royal Navy battle group, led by HMS Invincible, currently on its way to our region, or are there plans for a visit in the near future; if so, what is the nature of the visit and why was it scheduled for this particular time.
(2) Is the Minister for Defence aware of the type of weapons carried by the battle group; if so, can the Minister supply details of what they are.
(3) Are nuclear weapons included in the battle group's arsenal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As announced by the Acting Minister for Defence on 15 July 1983, a Royal Navy task group is to visit Australian ports between November and the beginning of January, as part of a deployment to the Indian and Pacific Oceans, New Zealand and the Far East.

(2) and (3) It has been the practice of successive Australian governments not to comment on the weapons systems of allied ships or aircraft, and to accept the policies of our allies of neither confirming nor denying the carriage of nuclear weapons.
